item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive overview of the American television series Resident Alien, detailing its genre, creators, cast, production, and reception.

General Information ðŸ”—

  • Genre: Comedy-drama, mystery, and science fiction.
  • Creator: Chris Sheridan.
  • Based on: The Resident Alien comic book series by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse.
  • Starring: Alan Tudyk, Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, Levi Fiehler, Judah Prehn, and Elizabeth Bowen.
  • Opening Theme: “Bilgewater” by Brown Bird.
  • Country of Origin: United States.
  • Original Language: English.
  • Number of Seasons: 3 (as of June 2024).
  • Number of Episodes: 34 (as of June 2024).
  • Production Locations: Delta, British Columbia, Canada.
  • Original Network: Syfy (Seasons 1-3).
  • Future Network: USA Network (Season 4 onwards).
  • Original Release: January 27, 2021 â€“ April 3, 2024.
  • Renewal: Renewed for a fourth season in June 2024, moving to USA Network.

Premise ðŸ”—

An alien crash-lands on Earth near a small town in Colorado. To blend in, it kills a vacationing physician named Harry Vanderspeigle and assumes his identity. The alien is tasked with performing an autopsy on the town’s deceased doctor and subsequently takes over his practice. The narrative explores the alien’s internal conflict regarding its mission to wipe out humanity, complicated by developing compassion and moral dilemmas. A key plot point involves the mayor’s son, Max, who can see through the alien’s disguise. As the series progresses, the alien must defend humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and Characters ðŸ”—

Main ðŸ”—

  • Alan Tudyk as Harry Vanderspeigle: An alien who assumes the identity of a doctor. Tudyk also portrays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle, a corrupt doctor. Stuntman Keith Arbuthnot portrays the alien in its true form. David Bianchi portrays Goliath, Harry’s future self.
  • Sara Tomko as Asta Twelvetrees: The doctor’s assistant and a member of the Ute Native American tribe.
  • Corey Reynolds as Sheriff Mike Thompson: The town’s sheriff, dealing with past insecurities.
  • Alice Wetterlund as D’arcy Bloom: The owner of the town pub and Asta’s best friend.
  • Levi Fiehler as Ben Hawthorne: The town’s young mayor, who has a history of alien abductions.
  • Judah Prehn as Max Hawthorne: Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s true alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen as Deputy Liv Baker: The town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrial life.

Recurring ðŸ”—

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest ðŸ”—

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes ðŸ”—

Series Overview ðŸ”—

The series consists of three seasons, with the first premiering on January 27, 2021, and the third concluding on April 3, 2024. The first season has 10 episodes, the second has 16, and the third has 8. The show originally aired on Syfy, but will move to USA Network for its fourth season.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

The first season consists of 10 episodes, starting with the “Pilot” directed by David Dobkin. The season follows the alien’s initial crash landing, assumption of Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle’s identity, and struggle to blend in while pursuing its mission. Key events include the discovery of the real Harry’s foot in the lake, the introduction of Max Hawthorne who can see the alien’s true form, and the arrival of the real Harry’s wife, Isabelle. The season culminates with Harry’s decision to spare humanity and his accidental stowaway, Max, on his ship.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

The second season is divided into two parts, each consisting of eight episodes. The season explores Harry’s attempts to prevent an alien invasion, his journey to New York, and the emergence of Goliath, his future self. Key events include Harry losing his memory, Asta discovering she has a daughter, and the introduction of new characters like Carlyn and Violinda Darvell. The season ends with Harry learning about Grey-human hybrids and the abduction of Ben Hawthorne.

Season 3 (2024) ðŸ”—

The third season consists of 8 episodes. Harry works with General McCallister to eliminate the Grey Alien threat. Asta and Harry work together to undermine Joseph, a Grey-human hybrid. Ben and Kate experience troubling visions related to their abductions. Harry has a romantic relationship with a Blue Avian alien named Heather. The season culminates with Harry’s bomb going missing, D’arcy taking the bomb to the Greys’ base, and the revelation that the Greys’ mother ship is actually Earth’s Moon.

Production ðŸ”—

Development ðŸ”—

Chris Sheridan was inspired by the Resident Alien comic book series and a personal “close encounter” experience. Syfy announced the TV adaptation in May 2018, with Sheridan as the show creator. The series was officially ordered in February 2019, with production based in Vancouver. David Dobkin directed the pilot, and Robert Duncan McNeill served as an executive producer and producing director. The series was renewed for a second season in March 2021 and a third season in July 2022. In June 2024, it was announced that the series was renewed for a fourth season and moving to the USA Network.

Casting ðŸ”—

Alan Tudyk was cast as the main character in September 2018, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, and Alex Barima were cast in recurring roles in January 2020, followed by Elizabeth Bowen in February 2020.

Filming ðŸ”—

Filming for the first season began in September 2020 and concluded in October 2020 in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. The second season was filmed between August 2021 and April 2022, with locations including Ladysmith, British Columbia. Filming for the third season began in January 2023 and concluded in May 2023. Filming for the fourth season began on December 2, 2024 and concluded on March 31, 2025.

Release ðŸ”—

Syfy initially announced a summer 2020 premiere, which was later moved to January 2021. The series premiered on January 27, 2021, in the United States and Canada, and on Sky One in the United Kingdom the following day.

Reception ðŸ”—

Critical Response ðŸ”—

The first season received positive reviews, with Rotten Tomatoes reporting a 94% approval rating based on 31 critic reviews. Metacritic gave the first season

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Alien abduction entities
item.description:
Alien Abduction Entities ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry focuses on the beings alleged to be responsible for alien abductions, particularly those involving forced medical examinations with an emphasis on the reproductive system. It highlights the skepticism surrounding the phenomenon within the scientific and mental health communities, attributing such experiences to psychological and environmental factors rather than literal events.

Alleged Motivations ðŸ”—

This section explores the purported reasons behind alien abductions, as claimed by experiencers. Dr. John G. Miller’s research indicates that abductees often report entities claiming a “right” to perform invasive procedures. UFOlogist Jenny Randles’ study of 50 abduction claims reveals that in approximately 60% of cases, abductors provided insights into their motivations, often involving long-term surveillance and interaction. These motivations form a narrative centered on the entities targeting individuals with unique qualities for repeated abductions, during which information is subconsciously implanted for later activation, potentially coinciding with major Earth changes. Different entity types, such as “Nordics” and “Grays,” are said to have varying motivations, with Nordics being perceived as more benevolent.

Types ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the different types of entities reported in alien abduction claims. It presents two tables summarizing these types based on different studies. The first table, based on a survey of 203 pre-1985 abduction claims, lists entities such as Short Humanoids (including short grey aliens), Average Height Humanoids (including tall grey aliens), Tall Humanoids, Mummy-like beings, Miscellaneous Humanoids (including reptoids and hairy dwarves), Human-like beings (including Nordics), and Non-human entities. The second table, based on Claudier Covo’s Brazilian Alien Typology from a study of 138 alleged abductions, categorizes entities as Alpha (0.8â€“1.4 m tall), Beta (1.4â€“2 m tall), Gamma (over 2 m tall), Delta (animals, robots, etc.), Omega (energy beings), and Sigma (very short beings about 0.15 m tall). The section also mentions “Mantid aliens” as frequently reported by abductees, often described as being in charge of the grays.

Reported Technology ðŸ”—

This section details the technological capabilities allegedly displayed by alien abduction entities. Claimants report being levitated, flown around, and witnessing entities passing through walls. Further claimed technical capabilities have been described â€“ including in various books by ufologists â€“ generally without any detailed hypotheses regarding how such appearances or actual capabilities may or may not be possible.

Weapon ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on a specific weapon allegedly used by grey aliens, as described in Nick Pope’s book The Uninvited. The device is described as a black, cylindrical object, similar in size to a pencil, with a bluish light on one end. It is reportedly used to subdue combative abductees by numbing their will, resembling a Star Trek “phaser” firing a bluish-white beam.

Medical ðŸ”—

This subsection describes a medical device reported by Linda Moulton Howe, based on independent reports from at least two alleged abductions. The device is a pencil-sized cylinder with a light on one end, used in a manner analogous to a surgical scalpel. One abductee described the device opening the chest bloodlessly in “slow motion,” comparing it to a flower blossoming in time-lapse photography, and described the device as “opening the body with sound.”

Plausibility and Veracity ðŸ”—

This section addresses the plausibility and veracity of alien abduction claims, particularly focusing on the influence of hypnosis, geography, culture, and science fiction on abductor descriptions.

Hypnosis as an Influence on Abductor Descriptions ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the impact of hypnosis on the descriptions of abducting beings. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard notes that the absence of monstrous types in reliable cases contradicts the idea that Hollywood influences abduction reports. He also observes that hypnotically assisted recall tends to produce descriptions of “standard” Grey humanoids, while cases without hypnosis include more variety. Bullard raises the question of whether hypnosis shapes memories or reveals the true appearance of the beings.

Geography and Culture as Influences on Abductor Descriptions ðŸ”—

This subsection explores how geographic and cultural factors influence the details of abduction reports. Robert Sheaffer observes that in North America, large-headed gray aliens are predominant, while in Britain, abduction aliens are usually tall, blond, and Nordic, and South America tends toward more bizarre creatures. The section also notes that common elements in abduction descriptions vary by region and local culture, with only a few elements being consistent worldwide, such as otherworldly sensations, mind control, repressed memories, and sexual experiences, which are also common in stories of encounters with faeries, demons, and other magical creatures. In Brazil, there are strong links between the abduction phenomenon and spiritist traditions, with claims of medical practitioners operating out of a space laboratory.

Science Fiction as an Influence ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the potential influence of science fiction on abduction reports. Sheaffer notes similarities between aliens depicted in early science fiction films, such as Invaders From Mars, and those reported to have abducted people. Commonalities exist in the appearances, behavior, technology, and societies of fictional and allegedly real abductors. The “abduction narrative” was already established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers comic strip. However, Bullard does not see evidence for influence on abduction claimants from science fiction sources.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_entities

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 ðŸ”—

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s a remote detachment administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s widely believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a central subject of conspiracy theories and UFO folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request.

Geography ðŸ”—

Area 51 ðŸ”—

The original rectangular base is part of the “Groom box,” a restricted airspace area. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and eventually connects with State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel, Nevada. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, the location of many nuclear tests. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake.

Groom Lake ðŸ”—

Groom Lake is a salt flat in Nevada used for runways of the Nellis Bombing Range Test Site airport (XTA/KXTA) on the north of the Area 51 USAF military installation. It’s located within the Groom Lake Valley portion of the Tonopah Basin, south of Rachel, Nevada.

History ðŸ”—

The origin of the name “Area 51” is unclear. The facility is also referred to as Homey Airport (XTA/KXTA) and Groom Lake. Other nicknames include “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace around the field is referred to as Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, leading to mining operations until the early 1950s. The airfield began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program ðŸ”—

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE: the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. sought a secure testing site. Lockheed’s Kelly Johnson identified Groom Lake as ideal. The CIA asked the AEC to acquire the land, designated “Area 51.” Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch.” The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. CIA, Air Force, and Lockheed personnel began arriving by July 1955.

OXCART program ðŸ”—

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. Construction of A-12 test facilities began in September 1960, including a new runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) upgraded base facilities. The contractor marked an Archimedean spiral on the dry lake. Security was enhanced, and the FAA expanded the restricted airspace. The CIA facility received various USAF aircraft for training and support. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived in February 1962 and made its first flight in April 1962. Groom was also the site of the first Lockheed D-21 drone test flight in December 1964. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron.”

D-21 Tagboard ðŸ”—

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2, there were discussions about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The Air Force agreed to fund the study of a high-speed, high-altitude drone aircraft in October 1962. The project designated “Q-12” was renamed the “D-21”. “Tagboard” was the project’s code name. The first D-21 was completed in the spring of 1964 by Lockheed. It was to be carried by a two-seat derivative of the A-12, designated the “M-21”. Difficulties were addressed throughout 1964 and 1965 at Groom Lake with various technical issues. The first D-21 launch was made on 5 March 1966 with a successful flight. An accident on 30 July 1966 with a fully fueled D-21 caused it to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft. Kelly Johnson personally cancelled the entire program. A number of D-21s had already been produced, and Johnson again proposed to the Air Force that they be launched from a B-52H bomber. Several more tests, including two over China, were made from Beale AFB, California, in 1969 and 1970, to varying degrees of success. On 15 July 1971, Kelly Johnson received a wire canceling the D-21B program.

Foreign technology evaluation ðŸ”—

During the Cold War, the United States tested and evaluated captured Soviet fighter aircraft. Beginning in the late 1960s, Area 51 hosted Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 from Iraq for Israel’s Mossad in Operation Diamond led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate the aircraft in performance, technical, and operational capabilities, pitting the types against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT in which Air Force Systems Command, Tactical Air Command, and the U.S. Navy’s Air Test and Evaluation Squadron Four (VX-4) flew this acquired Soviet-made aircraft in simulated air combat training. On 12 August 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants, Walid Adham and Radfan Rifai, took off in a pair of MiG-17Fs on a training mission. They lost their way and landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel. Prior to the end of 1968 these MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, which took over from the older HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE FERRY and HAVE DRILL projects, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. The Air Force began funding improvements to Area 51 in 1977 under project SCORE EVENT. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program ðŸ”—

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. In 1978, the Air Force awarded a full-scale development contract for the F-117 to Lockheed Corporation’s Advanced Development Projects. On 17 January 1981 the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype 79â€“780, designated YF-117A. On 18 June 1981 Lockheed Skunk Works test pilot Hal Farley lifted the nose of YF-117A 79â€“780 off the runway of Area 51. Tactical Air Command (TAC) decided to set up a group-level organization to guide the F-117A to an initial operating capability. That organization became the 4450th Tactical Group, which officially activated on 15 October 1979 at Nellis AFB, Nevada, although the group was physically located at Area 51. On 15 October 1982, Major Alton C. Whitley Jr. became the first USAF 4450th TG pilot to fly the F-117A. Tonopah Test Range Airport was selected for operations of the first USAF F-117 unit, the 4450th Tactical Group (TG). By early 1982, four more YF-117As were operating at the base. Testing of a series of ultra-secret prototypes continued at Area 51 until mid-1981 when testing transitioned to the initial production of F-117 stealth fighters. The F-117s were moved to and from Area 51 by C-5 during darkness to maintain security. While the “Baja Scorpions” were working on the F-117, there was also another group at work

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_51

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction ðŸ”—

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. Those who claim to have been abducted are referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” The prevailing scientific and mental health perspective attributes these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology. Skeptics note similarities between alien descriptions and those in science fiction films.

Overview ðŸ”—

Mainstream scientists generally dismiss claims of literal alien abduction. However, some researchers, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals. A subculture has developed around the phenomenon, complete with support groups and a detailed mythos involving various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics) with specific roles and motivations. Some abductees explain the lack of wider awareness as a result of extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History ðŸ”—

Paleo-abductions ðŸ”—

This section discusses older stories that some UFO researchers, like Jerome Clark, have interpreted as possible early cases of alien abduction, termed “paleo-abductions.” Examples include:

  • A November 27, 1896, report in The Evening Mail of Stockton, California, where Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them.
  • A 1953 Man to Man Magazine article by Leroy Thorpe, questioning if humans were being captured by flying saucers for experimentation.
  • Harold T. Wilkins’s 1955 publication Flying Saucers Uncensored, which reported the mysterious disappearance of Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who had claimed contact with aliens, suggesting they might have been abducted.

Two Landmark Cases ðŸ”—

This section highlights two early alien abduction claims that gained significant attention:

  • The AntÃ´nio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil in the mid-1950s.
  • The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961, which received widespread publicity and was dramatized in a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, introducing the beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identifying an extraterrestrial origin.

Skeptic Peter Rogerson notes that these cases established a template for later abduction reports.

Later Developments ðŸ”—

This section discusses the evolution of the alien abduction phenomenon and the involvement of key figures:

  • R. Leo Sprinkle, a University of Wyoming psychologist, became interested in abductions in the 1960s and linked them to cattle mutilation.
  • Budd Hopkins, an artist interested in UFOs, began using hypnosis in the 1970s to uncover details of abduction experiences, becoming a figurehead in the abductee subculture.
  • The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience.
  • Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published in the 1980s.
  • Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was far more common than previously suspected and that aliens were attempting to create human-alien hybrids.

According to Linda Rodriguez McRobbie of the Boston Globe, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media in recent decades. Michael Shermer suggests that camera phones have increased the burden of evidence for such claims.

John E. Mack ðŸ”—

This section focuses on Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack, who believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, criticized Mack for uncritically elaborating on abduction tales and potentially creating false memories. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject, but his professional reputation suffered as a result.

Abductees ðŸ”—

This section discusses the demographics and mental health of alleged abductees. The precise number of abductees is uncertain, with estimates ranging from 1,700 claimants in early studies to 5â€“6 percent of the general population in contested surveys.

Demographics ðŸ”—

Reports are usually made by adults, but sometimes young children report similar experiences. These child-reports often feature very specific details in common with reports of abduction made by adults, including the circumstances, narrative, entities and aftermaths of the alleged occurrences. Often, these young abductees have family members who have reported having abduction experiences. Family involvement in the military, or a residence near a military base is also common among child abduction claimants.

Mental Health ðŸ”—

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that “as a group, abduction experients are not different from the general population in term of psychopathology prevalence”. Elizabeth Slater conducted a blind study of nine abduction claimants and found them to be prone to “mildly paranoid thinking”, nightmares and having a weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally of Harvard Medical School concluded in a similar study of 10 abductees that “none of them was suffering from any sort of psychiatric illness.”

Political Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section explores the connections between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, and government cover-ups. Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights the rise of “improvisional millenarism” and the role of UFO and abduction stories in stigmatized knowledge narratives. He notes the emergence of alien-related conspiracy theories in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards. TV shows like The X-Files are mentioned as examples of popular culture incorporating alien conspiracies. Jodi Dean notes that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities. Self-described abduction victims may join self-help communities and espouse conspiracy theories involving mind control and a New World Order.

Abduction Narrative ðŸ”—

This section outlines the common elements and sequence of events reported in abduction narratives. According to CUFOS’s definition of abductee, the person must have been taken against their will by apparent non-human beings, taken to a special place perceived as extraterrestrial or to be a spaceship. They then must experience being subjected to an examination or to engage in some form of communication with the beings (or both). Communication may be perceived as telepathic rather than verbal. The memory of the experience may be conscious or “recovered” through means like hypnosis.

Thomas E. Bullard argues that there is a broad, fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.” These events include:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures.
  3. Conference: Communication with the abductors, typically telepathically.
  4. Tour: A tour of the captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Rapid forgetting of the experience.
  6. Return: Return to Earth, sometimes in a different location.
  7. Theophany: A profound sense of love or a mystical experience.
  8. Aftermath: Coping with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs emphasizes the orchestrated nature of the abduction event.

Capture ðŸ”—

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience. These feelings manifest as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place at a certain time or as expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will soon occur. Abductees also report feeling severe, undirected anxiety at this point even though nothing unusual has actually occurred yet. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. As consciousness shifts one or more lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, in the latter case often through solid objects such as walls, ceilings or a closed window.

Examination ðŸ”—

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations performed by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. These procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. John G. Miller notes differences between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors.

Subsequent Procedures ðŸ”—

After the medical exam, abductees often report other procedures, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

  • “Imaging” involves viewing screens displaying emotionally provocative images.
  • “Envisioning” involves images projected into the experiencer’s mind.
  • “Staging” involves the abductee interacting with an illusionary scenario.
  • “Testing” involves operating a complicated electronic device.

Child Presentation ðŸ”—

Abductees sometimes report being shown a “child” who appears to be a hybrid between humans and their abductors. Thomas E. Bullard could not identify a child presentation phase in the abduction narrative, even after undertaking a study of 300 abduction reports.

Less Common Elements ðŸ”—

Bullard’s study of 300 abduction reports also identified less prominent aspects of the claims, including:

  1. The conference
  2. The tour
  3. The journey
  4. Theophany

These episodes tend to happen between the medical examination and the return.

Return ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction

item.title: Alien Autopsy (1995 television film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (1995 television film) ðŸ”—

This article discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The article distinguishes this footage from the 2006 film Alien Autopsy, which is a fictionalized account of the events surrounding the creation and release of the footage.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the production of the hoaxed alien autopsy footage. In 2006, Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the 1995 footage. They filmed a simulated autopsy on a fabricated alien in a set constructed in a London living room. Artist and sculptor John Humphreys constructed two dummy alien bodies filled with raspberry jam, sheep brains, and chicken entrails. Humphreys also played the role of the chief examiner. Alien artifacts were also created by Humphreys. Santilli and Shoefield also admitted to finding a homeless man in Los Angeles and paying him to play the role of the cameraman.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section discusses how Alien Autopsy was received and satirized in the media. The X-Files featured alien autopsy footage that was decried as a hoax. Fox aired a special debunking the 1995 footage. A fictionalized version of the creation of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers who want to learn more about the alien autopsy hoax.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to the alien autopsy hoax, including an article by Ray Santilli and links to his IMDb page and a YouTube video of Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction?

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation ðŸ”—

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon is often linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. Mutilations typically involve the removal of specific body parts such as ears, eyeballs, jaw flesh, tongues, lymph nodes, genitals, and rectums. Two independent federal investigations have been conducted in the United States to examine these incidents.

Early History ðŸ”—

The earliest documented cases of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Whole slaughters of sheep were reported, with only tallow and some inward parts taken. Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 ðŸ”—

Unexplained livestock deaths gained wider attention in 1967 with the case of “Snippy,” a horse found mutilated in Alamosa, Colorado. The Pueblo Chieftain published a story about the incident, noting the horse’s head and neck had been skinned and defleshed with precise cuts, and there was no blood at the scene. This case was the first to link extraterrestrial beings and UFOs to mutilations. Wadsworth Ayer investigated the case for the Condon Committee and concluded there was no evidence to support the assertion that the horse’s death was associated with abnormal causes. Alamosa County Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike as the cause. Later press coverage mentioned the horse had been shot. Two students from Alamosa State College confessed to shooting the horse several weeks after the case was publicized.

Cattle Mutilations 1973â€“1980 ðŸ”—

Waves of cattle mutilations were reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico during this period. In April 1973, sheriffs in Western Iowa reported unidentified helicopters involved in cattle and pig rustling. Similar rustling was reported in Missouri in August.

1973 Kansas Wave ðŸ”—

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about a caller posing as a USDA official conducting a survey of herd population and locations. A series of butchered cows were found on farms near Munden, Kansas. The right ear was often removed. Local press speculated about a ‘Mad Dog’ or ‘phantom’ Butcher. By December, law enforcement reported investigating 40 mutilations across Kansas and Nebraska. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a cattle mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office determined that most of the deaths and removal of sex organs were the result of natural causes including predation, “[shipping fever](Shipping fever)” and [blackleg](Blackleg_(disease). Modlin disagreed with these conclusions.

1974 Nebraska Wave ðŸ”—

Reports resumed in April 1974, when a Nebraska cow was discovered mutilated and drained of blood. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations along with sightings of unidentified helicopters. In May, two mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa. By June 1974, mutilations were reported in Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer Country reported similar helicopter sightings and armed patrols. On August 14, 1974, the Cascade County, Montana Sheriff’s Office received its first report of a mutilated cow. An unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering 400 feet above where a mutilated cow would later be discovered near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported that armed civilians had begun patrols in response to repeated helicopter sightings. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh told press of a jailhouse informant who claimed to be a former cult member and opined the mutilations were likely the result of devil-worshiping cultists. State Sen. John Decamp called on authorities to coordinate an investigation into the mutilations. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when he found a helicopter above his field. Authorities cautioned the public not to shoot at aircraft. Over 50 law enforcement officials from 24 counties attended a meeting at the Knox County Courthouse in Center, Nebraska to discuss the mutilations. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande told press that a number of mutilations had been reported in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek released a statement denying any link between UFOs and cattle mutilations.

1975 Colorado ðŸ”—

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI asking for help due to public concern. He claimed there had been 130 mutilations in Colorado alone, and further reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report indicated that, according to investigations by the New Mexico State Police, there had been an estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing approximately $1 million in damages. In January 1975, the Michigan ATF tasked Donald E. Flickinger with investigating the mutilations. In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under the leadership of Carl Whiteside.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico ðŸ”—

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting ðŸ”—

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz approached Valdez and reported having seen unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. On May 2, 1979, Valdez told press that two drugs had been found in the remains of a mutilated bull found in Torrance County on February 15. On June 14, 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with a large amount of radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents ðŸ”—

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since the 1967 Snippy incident, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002. In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated male human corpse that was found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil in 1988.

Characteristics ðŸ”—

Cattle death due to natural causes are extremely common. Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts were described as “clean” and “surgical”. Some animals were reported to have been drained of blood but with no sign of blood in the immediate area or even around their wounds. According to Howard Burgess, nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. In some cases, strange marks or imprints near the site have been found.

Laboratory Reports ðŸ”—

Laboratory reports carried out on some mutilated animals have shown unusually high or low levels of vitamins or minerals in tissue samples, and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In one case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI, an 11-month-old cross Hereford-Charolais bull, belonging to a Mr. Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, was found mutilated on March 24, 1978. Los Alamos detected the presence of naturally occurring Clostridium bacteria in the heart. Samples from the animal’s liver were found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain 4 times the normal level of zinc, potassium and phosphorus. Blood samples taken at the scene were reported to be “light pink in color” and “Did not clot after several days”.

Helicopter Sightings ðŸ”—

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters were reported to have opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. while he was driving his tractor on his farm in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported that residents had seen unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups to patrol their fields at night. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted several men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter at a small community airport in Cache County. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft which resembled a U.S. military helicopter hovering around a site following a wave of alleged mutilation which claimed 16 cows.

Official Investigations ðŸ”—

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover to investigate. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation of the mutilation phenomenon.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms ðŸ”—

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched their own investigation into the phenomenon, headed by Agent Donald Flickinger. Flickinger was tasked with investigating the possible connections between cults and the mutilation of cattle. Flickinger recorded a number of “unusual” incidents and circumstantial evidence, but was unable to find sufficient evidence of cult involvement for the ATF to take further action.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation ðŸ”—

In May 197

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle_mutilation

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry delves into the world of UFO conspiracy theories, exploring the belief that governments, particularly the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life and technology. It examines the historical development of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: the alleged suppression of evidence regarding extraterrestrial-controlled UFOs or technology. It notes the evolution of these theories, from initial claims of government cover-ups to more complex narratives involving communication and cooperation with extraterrestrials, including claims of government allowance of cattle mutilation and alien abduction. It also mentions the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry’s stance that there is little to no evidence supporting these theories.

Mainstream Views ðŸ”—

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It highlights government and independent investigations that have failed to confirm extraordinary claims made by ufologists. Prosaic explanations for UFO sightings, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes, are offered. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs and their influence on new religions. Benjamin Radford’s argument about the unlikelihood of a decades-long, international cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents ðŸ”—

This section identifies key figures associated with UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent voices from the 1950s to the 1970s. It also notes that some early proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, suffered from psychiatric issues, and that some proponents confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists individuals in positions of authority, such as Senator Barry Goldwater, Admiral Lord Hill-Norton, Vice Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, and astronauts Gordon Cooper and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents like Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction ðŸ”—

This section explores the portrayal of government cover-ups of extraterrestrial contact in popular fiction. Films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black are cited as examples. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned. The section also notes John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, Sidney Sheldon’s novel The Doomsday Conspiracy, and the series American Horror Story: Double Feature.

In Religion ðŸ”—

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and religion. It identifies new religious movements, including the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate, that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology, Theosophy, and the “I AM” Activity are also discussed. The section mentions the Nation of Islam’s concept of “The Mother Plane,” the UFO religions Unarius and the Aetherius Society, L. Ron Hubbard’s teachings about Xenu in Scientology, and the RaÃ«lism movement. It concludes with the Heaven’s Gate mass suicide and the Order of the Solar Temple mass deaths.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine Amazing Stories in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his publication of Richard Shaver’s stories about a secret underground race and Palmer’s claim that world governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” ðŸ”—

This subsection details Richard Shaver’s claims of telepathic communication with a secret underground race and their mastery of space travel. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the beginning of the flying disc craze with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting in 1947. It mentions the Roswell incident and the Army’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc.” It also discusses Palmer’s investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington, and the subsequent plane crash.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the aftermath of the Maury Island incident and the continued promotion of UFO conspiracy theories by Palmer and Shaver. It mentions Shaver’s “rock books” and Palmer’s later admission that Shaver had spent time in a mental institution. It also notes Palmer’s claim of a link between flying saucers, the Shaver Mystery, the Kennedy assassination, Watergate, and Fred Crisman.

National Coverage in the 1950s ðŸ”—

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence in the 1950s.

The Flying Saucer Conspiracy ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on Donald Keyhoe’s role in promoting UFO conspiracy theories in the 1950s. It mentions his article “The Flying Saucers Are Real” and his book The Flying Saucer Conspiracy, which accused the government of covering up knowledge of flying saucers. It also describes Keyhoe’s appearance on CBS’s Armstrong Circle Theatre and the cutting of his microphone during the live broadcast.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s “alien bodies” conspiracy theory, which claimed that dead extraterrestrial beings were recovered from a flying saucer crash. It mentions Scully’s book Behind the Flying Saucers and the later exposure of Scully as a victim of confidence artists.

Air Force Accounts ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings in the 1950s. It mentions General John Samford’s press conference on the Washington D.C. UFO incident, the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education, and Al Chop’s role as the press spokesman for Project Bluebook. It also discusses Captain Edward J. Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax ðŸ”—

This subsection describes the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, which involved claims of a navy ship being made invisible and teleporting. It mentions Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende” (Carl Meredith Allen). It also discusses the annotated copy of Jessup’s book and Jessup’s death by suicide.

‘Men in Black’ Legends ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the legend of the Men in Black, popularized by Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers. It mentions the speculation that the men in black are government agents who harass and threaten UFO witnesses.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government ðŸ”—

This section discusses the growing government skepticism in the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the 1966 UFO reports in Michigan and the Air Force’s explanation that they were caused by swamp gas. It notes the ridicule that followed and the call for a Congressional investigation.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This subsection details Fred Crisman’s involvement in the JFK assassination conspiracy theories. It mentions Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and Crisman’s testimony before the New Orleans grand jury.

“Cosmic Watergate” ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” referring to a government cover-up of UFO information. It mentions the film 2001: A Space Odyssey and J. Allen Hynek’s claim that Bluebook was a “Cosmic Watergate.”

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the legends of alien bodies being stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. It mentions Robert Spencer Carr’s claim that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored there.

“Alien Abductions” ðŸ”—

This subsection covers the rise of alien abduction claims in the 1970s. It mentions the Betty and Barney Hill case, the Travis Walton incident, and the work of Budd Hopkins and Whitley Strieber.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind ðŸ”—

This subsection explores the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the film’s depiction of a government cover-up and the involvement of J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallee.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell ðŸ”—

This subsection details Jesse Marcel’s role in the Roswell incident and his later statements suggesting that the debris might have been extraterrestrial. It mentions the National Enquirer’s coverage of the story and the US military’s later reports disclosing the true nature of the crashed aircraft.

Doty and Lear Promote the “Dark Side ðŸ”—

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_conspiracy_theories

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens ðŸ”—

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the Grey alien image. These beings have become an archetypal representation of intelligent non-human creatures and extraterrestrial life in popular culture.

Description ðŸ”—

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are generally described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin and reduced or absent external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. They have disproportionately large heads, no hair, and small openings for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their most striking feature is their large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance ðŸ”—

This subsection elaborates on the physical appearance of Greys. They are typically depicted as grey-skinned, small humanoids with reduced or absent external human body parts. Their bodies are elongated, with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. They have unusually large heads in proportion to their bodies, no hair, and no noticeable outer ears or noses. They are almost always shown with very large, opaque, black eyes, without eye whites, and are frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association originated with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed to have been shown a map displaying the aliens’ home system and nearby stars. Fish created a model from Hill’s drawing and determined that the stars marked as the aliens’ home were Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. Descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate claims of encounters with them. H.G. Wells described humans with similar features in his writings from the late 19th century. Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a similar entity named Lam as early as 1917. Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described similar aliens in his 1933 science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Origins ðŸ”—

This subsection details the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien archetype. In 1893, H.G. Wells described humanity’s future appearance as lacking mouths, noses, or hair, and with large heads. In 1895, Wells depicted the Eloi in similar terms in The Time Machine. As early as 1917, Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, similar in appearance to a modern Grey. In 1933, Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, published The Unknown Danger, describing extraterrestrials with grey fabric clothes, short stature, big bald heads, and large, dark, gleaming eyes.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction ðŸ”—

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. Newspaper reports of the Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1965 made the archetype famous. The Hills claimed that in 1961, grey-skinned humanoid alien beings abducted them and took them to a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield.” Carl Sagan echoed Kottmeyer’s suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses how Greys became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hills’ encounter. According to journalist C.D.B. Bryan, 73% of all reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. In the early 1980s, Greys were linked to the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published the book Communion, describing his alleged close encounters with Greys and other extraterrestrial beings. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu described “the little greys” on French television. In 1995, Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage depicting the autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from the Roswell incident.

Analysis ðŸ”—

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology ðŸ”—

This subsection examines the role of Greys in alien abduction claims and ufology. Greys are often involved in alien abduction claims, making up about 50% of reports in Australia, 73% in the United States, 48% in continental Europe, and around 12% in the United Kingdom. These reports include two distinct groups of Greys that differ in height. Abduction claims are often described as extremely traumatic. The eyes are often a focus of abduction claims, with Greys staring into the eyes of abductees when conducting mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence ðŸ”—

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing everything that modern humans traditionally link with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” ðŸ”—

This subsection introduces Frederick V. Malmstrom’s idea that Greys are actually residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom reconstructs the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face based on our best understanding of early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility ðŸ”—

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be credible as a representation of an alien from a world with different environmental and ecological conditions.

Other hypotheses ðŸ”—

This subsection mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section discusses the prevalence of Grey aliens in popular culture. Depictions of Grey aliens have appeared in numerous films and television shows, supplanting the previously popular little green men. Examples include Ultraman, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. During the 1990s, plotlines wherein Greys were linked to conspiracy theories became common, such as in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The 2011 film Paul tells the story of a Grey named Paul who attributes the Greys’ frequent presence in science fiction pop culture to the US government deliberately inserting the stereotypical Grey alien image into mainstream media. Child abduction by Greys is a key plot point in the 2013 film, Dark Skies. Greys appear in Syfy’s 2021 science fiction dramedy series Resident Alien. The Greys appear as the main antagonistic faction in the 2023 independent game Greyhill Incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_alien

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Nordic Aliens ðŸ”—

In ufology, “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites” are terms used to describe alleged humanoid extraterrestrial races from the Pleiades star cluster. These beings are said to resemble Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans, with features like tall stature (6-7 ft), blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some reports describe their skin tone as pale blue/grey or pastel purple.

History ðŸ”—

Cultural historian David J. Skal suggests that early stories of Nordic aliens may have been inspired by the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still. Stephanie Kelley-Romano describes alien abduction beliefs as a “living myth,” noting that believers often associate Nordic aliens with spiritual growth and protection.

In ufology, Nordic aliens are often portrayed as benevolent beings concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic powers and described as paternal, watchful, smiling, affectionate, and youthful.

During the 1950s, many people, especially in Europe, claimed encounters with these beings. However, such claims became less common in later decades as the grey alien became more prevalent in extraterrestrial encounter accounts.

Publications by Those Claiming to Have Been Contacted ðŸ”—

Several books detail alleged personal contact with Nordic aliens, including:

  • Flying Saucers Have Landed by Desmond Leslie and George Adamski
  • Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski
  • From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger
  • The Walton Experience by Travis Walton
  • Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall (adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites)

The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions with “Cosmic Friends.”

See Also ðŸ”—

This section lists related topics, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of cited sources used in the article, including books, articles, and websites.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: White Orb Watches Family BBQ Over Lakeland, Florida
item.description:
An eyewitness at a family BBQ were enjoying the day when someone pointed out a white orb in the sky above. Then others came and they noticed it stayed over them as if it were watching them and recording the humans reactions to what they were seeing. You see, aliens love knowledge, like humans like money, knowledge is everything to them. The smaller orb drones are sent out from a mother drone and months later gathered after the orbs have recorded information about anything and everything they saw.

source: https://www.ufosightingsdaily.com/2025/04/white-orb-watches-family-bbq-over.html

item.title: Alien Hive
item.description:
Alien Hive ðŸ”—

Alien Hive is a puzzle video game developed and published by Malaysia-based studio Appxplore. It was released in March 2013 for iOS, Android, and Windows Phone platforms. The game combines match-three and sliding puzzle mechanics.

Gameplay ðŸ”—

The core gameplay involves swiping tiles to match eggs and aliens, with the goal of hatching, breeding, and evolving them into the Supreme Alien. Players aim to build the ultimate alien hive by matching resource tiles. Players must avoid Naughty Bots and use power-ups to eliminate them, while also trying to minimize the number of moves used. As players progress, they encounter more aliens and uncover their mysteries.

Magic Fruit, collected by merging seeds into saplings, is essential for evolving Supreme Aliens. These fruits allow players to merge similar-level items using only two of a kind instead of three. Evolved Supreme Aliens can be activated using gold to provide special bonuses in future games.

In App Purchase ðŸ”—

Alien Hive incorporates microtransactions, where players can exchange real money for in-game gold to purchase consumable items. This aspect of the game has faced criticism, with some reviewers suggesting that microtransactions are almost necessary to progress.

Reception ðŸ”—

Alien Hive received an average score of 70 out of 100 based on reviews aggregated by Metacritic.

By 2015, the game had achieved over 3 million downloads across all platforms.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including links to the game’s page on Appxplore’s website, the Google Play Store, and reviews from sites like Gamezebo and Vulcan Post. These references provide verification for the information presented in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to the official website of Alien Hive.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Hive

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no such life has been conclusively detected, it could range from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The study of extraterrestrial life falls under the domain of astrobiology.

Context ðŸ”—

This section provides a framework for understanding the conditions necessary for life in the universe. It begins with the Big Bang and the early universe, highlighting the initial extreme temperatures and the subsequent formation of elements like carbon and oxygen through stellar fusion. The emergence of planetary systems and organic compounds in protoplanetary disks is discussed, leading to the possibility of abiogenesis on planets like Earth. The concept of panspermia, the spread of life between habitable planets, is also introduced.

The context extends to Earth’s place in the Solar System, the Milky Way galaxy, and the larger universe, emphasizing the vast distances that pose challenges to studying extraterrestrial life. The limitations of current technology, such as probes and telescopes, are acknowledged. The circumstellar habitable zone, or “Goldilocks zone,” is explained as an area around a star where liquid water could exist on a planet’s surface, but it’s noted that habitability is complex and depends on various factors. The section concludes by considering the age of the universe and the possibility that life on other planets may have emerged and become extinct long ago. Avi Loeb’s “Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe” is mentioned, suggesting a period shortly after the Big Bang when conditions might have been suitable for primitive life. The adaptability of life on Earth, even in extreme environments, is highlighted, but it’s also noted that habitability does not guarantee the presence of life.

Likelihood of Existence ðŸ”—

This section explores the debate over whether life in the cosmos is common or rare. The hypothesis of ubiquitous extraterrestrial life rests on the size and age of the universe, the ubiquity of life’s chemical elements, and the universality of physical laws. Scientists like Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking are mentioned as proponents of this view, which is embodied in the Copernican and mediocrity principles.

The Rare Earth hypothesis, which posits that life on Earth is possible due to a unique combination of factors, is presented as an opposing viewpoint. The Drake equation, devised by Frank Drake, is introduced as a probabilistic argument to estimate the number of communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy. The equation’s variables, such as the rate of star formation and the fraction of planets that support life, are explained. The Drake equation is controversial because many of its values are speculative. The section concludes by discussing the Fermi paradox, the apparent contradiction between high estimates of the probability of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for their existence. Dennis W. Sciama, Zhi-Wei Wang, and Samuel L. Braunstein’s contributions to the Fermi Paradox are mentioned.

Biochemical Basis ðŸ”—

This section discusses the potential forms and requirements of extraterrestrial life. It considers a range of possibilities, from simple microorganisms to complex alien intelligences. The basic requirements for life, such as non-equilibrium thermodynamics and a source of energy, are outlined. Stars, volcanoes, plate tectonics, and hydrothermal vents are mentioned as potential energy sources.

The importance of liquid water as a solvent for biochemical reactions is emphasized, but alternatives like ammonia and liquid hydrocarbons are also considered. The section explores the chemical elements that could compose extraterrestrial life, focusing on carbon and potential replacements like silicon. The advantages and disadvantages of silicon-based life are discussed. Norman Horowitz’s view on the versatility of carbon is noted.

The section also considers the potential for radically different biochemistries, even if life is based on carbon and water. The requirements for natural selection, such as replication, damage avoidance, and resource acquisition, are outlined. The evolution from simple cells to eukaryotes and multicellular organisms is discussed, along with the possibility of convergent evolution leading to similar lifeforms on other planets. Simon Conway Morris’s ideas on convergent evolution are mentioned. Research assessing the capacity of life for developing intelligence is also noted.

Harsh Environmental Conditions on Earth Harboring Life ðŸ”—

This section addresses the common perception that the harsh conditions on other planets make them unlikely to harbor life. It presents evidence that some of the earliest and most basic forms of life on Earth originated in extreme environments, such as hydrothermal vents and acidic hot springs.

The section highlights the chemosynthetic processes that occur around hydrothermal vents, allowing organisms to utilize energy through reduced chemical compounds that fix carbon. These reactions enable organisms to live in low-oxygen environments. The early Earth environment was reducing, making these carbon-fixing compounds essential for survival. The section suggests that similar processes could occur on other planets with reducing atmospheres, potentially leading to the origin of extraterrestrial life.

Planetary Habitability in the Solar System ðŸ”—

This section examines the potential for life on other bodies within our Solar System. Besides Earth, Mars, Europa, and Enceladus are identified as the most likely candidates.

Venus is discussed as a terrestrial planet that may have once been similar to Earth, but now has a runaway greenhouse effect and a thick carbon-dioxide atmosphere. The possibility of microbial life in high-altitude clouds is mentioned. Mars is described as a cold, airless desert, but with evidence of abundant water in the past, suggesting it may have been habitable. The loss of its magnetic field and atmosphere is noted.

The gas giants and ice giants are considered unlikely to harbor life, but their moons are of interest. Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto are mentioned as having subsurface oceans, with Europa being the most promising due to contact between its ocean and rocky surface. Enceladus, a moon of Saturn, is highlighted for its eruption columns that release water into space, containing complex organic molecules, salts, hydrogen, and methane. Titan, another moon of Saturn, is unique for having liquid bodies on its surface, composed of hydrocarbons, but its cold temperatures may limit chemical activity.

Scientific Search ðŸ”—

This section outlines the scientific methods used to search for extraterrestrial life. Astrobiology, the science that studies life in the universe, is introduced. It encompasses various scientific disciplines, including astronomy, biology, chemistry, geology, oceanography, and atmospheric sciences.

The scientific search for extraterrestrial life is being carried out both directly and indirectly. The discovery of thousands of exoplanets is mentioned, along with the potential for primitive life on other planets and moons in the Solar System. Studies considering the possible detection of lifeforms on Venus (via phosphine) and Mars (via methane) are noted.

Search for Basic Life ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the search for biosignatures, indicators of life, within the Solar System and beyond. Scientists study planetary surfaces and examine meteorites for evidence of past or present life.

The controversial report of nanobacteria-like structures in the ALH84001 meteorite, originating from Mars, is mentioned. The Viking Mars landers’ gas emission experiments, which some scientists interpret as evidence of living microorganisms, are discussed. NASA’s Mars Science Laboratory and the Curiosity rover’s mission to assess past and present habitability on Mars are highlighted.

The development of a catalog of microorganisms and their reactions to sunlight is mentioned as a tool for identifying similar organisms on exoplanets. The discovery of nucleobases in meteorites found in Antarctica is noted, suggesting that organic molecules may be generated within asteroids and comets. The presence of complex organic compounds in cosmic dust is also mentioned. The detection of glycolaldehyde, a sugar molecule needed to form RNA, in a distant star system is highlighted. The discovery of hydrogen cyanide in the plumes of Enceladus is mentioned as a possible chemical essential for life.

Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligences ðŸ”—

This section shifts the focus to the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). It discusses the possibility of detecting civilizations through technosignatures, effects on their native planet that may not be caused by natural causes.

Interstellar communications, atmospheric effects, and planetary-sized structures like Dyson spheres are mentioned as potential technosignatures. Organizations like the SETI Institute search for radio waves and laser pulses. The challenges of distinguishing artificial signals from natural sources and the limitations of current telescopes are acknowledged.

The potential for detecting nitrogen dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons, and light pollution in exoplanet atmospheres is discussed. The Kardashev scale, which proposes that civilizations may eventually consume energy directly from their local star, is introduced. The possibility of detecting heavy elements in a star’s light spectrum as evidence of nuclear waste disposal is also mentioned.

Extrasolar Planets ðŸ”—

This section discusses the search for exoplanets that may be conducive to life. Astronomers focus on terrestrial planets within the habitable zones of their stars.

The discovery of thousands of exoplanets is mentioned, ranging in size from Earth-like to gas giants. The Kepler space telescope’s detection of thousands of candidate planets is highlighted. The estimate that there is at least one planet per star and that a significant fraction of Sun-like stars have Earth-sized planets in the habitable zone is noted.

The nearest known exoplanet, Proxima Centauri b, is mentioned. The least massive and most massive exoplanets known are identified. The study of planetary habitability considers a wide range of factors in determining the suitability of a planet for hosting life. The presence of oxygen in a planet’s atmosphere is mentioned as a potential sign of life. The use of spectrography to analyze exoplanet atmospheres during transit is discussed.

History and Cultural Impact ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical development of ideas about extraterrestrial life and its cultural influence.

Cosmic Pluralism ðŸ”—

This section traces the concept of

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Crop circle
item.description:
Crop Circle ðŸ”—

A crop circle, also known as a crop formation or corn circle, is a pattern created by flattening a crop, usually a cereal. The term was coined in the early 1980s. While fringe theorists suggest obscure natural causes or alien origins, there is no scientific evidence for such explanations, and all crop circles are consistent with human causation. In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, two hoaxers, claimed responsibility for creating over 200 crop circles throughout England. Reported circles in the United Kingdom appear near roads, areas of medium to dense population, and cultural heritage monuments, such as Stonehenge or Avebury, and usually appear overnight. Archaeological remains can cause cropmarks in the fields in the shapes of circles and squares, but these do not appear overnight, and are always in the same places every year.

History ðŸ”—

Before the 20th century ðŸ”—

A 1678 news pamphlet The Mowing-Devil: or, Strange News Out of Hartfordshire describes a crop whose stalks were cut rather than bent. In 1686, English naturalist Robert Plot reported on rings or arcs of mushrooms in The Natural History of Stafford-Shire, proposing air flows from the sky as a cause. In 1991, meteorologist Terence Meaden linked this report with modern crop circles. An 1880 letter to the editor of Nature by amateur scientist John Rand Capron describes how several circles of flattened crops in a field were formed under suspicious circumstances and possibly caused by “cyclonic wind action”.

20th century ðŸ”—

In 1932, archaeologist E. C. Curwen observed four dark rings in a field at Stoughton Down near Chichester. In Fortean Times, David Wood reported that in 1940 he made crop circles near Gloucestershire using ropes. In 1963, Patrick Moore described a crater in a potato field in Wiltshire and several circular and elliptical areas in nearby wheat fields. Astronomer Hugh Ernest Butler observed similar craters and said they were likely caused by lightning strikes. During the 1960s, there were many reports of UFO sightings and circular formations in swamp reeds and sugarcane fields in Tully, Queensland, Australia, and in Canada. On 8 August 1967, three circles were found in a field in Duhamel, Alberta, Canada; Department of National Defence investigators concluded that it was artificial. The most famous case is the 1966 Tully “saucer nest”. British pranksters Doug Bower and Dave Chorley reported they started creating crop circles in British cornfields in 1978, inspired by the Tully “saucer nest” case. The first film to depict a geometric crop circle, in this case created by super-intelligent ants, was the 1974 science-fiction film Phase IV. The majority of reports of crop circles have appeared and spread since the late 1970s. By 2001, approximately 10,000 crop circles have been reported internationally.

21st century ðŸ”—

Since the start of the 21st century, crop formations have increased in size and complexity. The researcher Jeremy Northcote found that crop circles in the UK in 2002 were not spread randomly across the landscape. They tended to appear near roads, areas of medium-to-dense population, and cultural heritage monuments such as Stonehenge or Avebury.

Bower and Chorley ðŸ”—

In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, made headlines by saying they had started the crop circle phenomenon in 1978, using simple tools. To prove their case they made a circle in front of journalists; a “cereologist”, Pat Delgado, examined the circle and declared it authentic before it was revealed that it was a hoax. Inspired by Australian crop circle accounts from 1966, Bower and Chorley claimed to be responsible for all circles made prior to 1987, and for more than 200 crop circles in 1978â€“1991.
