Art and business ðŸ”—

After reports of simple circles in the 1970s, increasingly complex geometric designs have been created by anonymous artists, in some cases to attract tourists to an area. Since the early 1990s, the UK arts collective Circlemakers, founded by Rod Dickinson and John Lundberg, has been creating crop circles in the UK and around the world as part of its art practice and also for commercial clients. The Led Zeppelin Boxed Set that was released on 7 September 1990, features an image of a crop circle that appeared in East Field in Alton Barnes, Wiltshire. On the night of 11â€“12 July 1992, a crop-circle-making competition with a prize of Â£3,000 was held in Berkshire. In 2002, Discovery Channel commissioned five aeronautics and astronautics graduate students from MIT to create crop circles of their own. In 2009, The Guardian reported that crop circle activity had been waning around Wiltshire, in part because makers preferred creating promotional crop circles for companies that paid well for their efforts. A video sequence used in connection with the opening of the 2012 Summer Olympics in London showed two crop circles in the shape of the Olympic rings. A 3 ha (7 acres) crop circle depicting the emblem of the Star Wars Rebel Alliance was created in California in December 2017.

Legal implications ðŸ”—

In 1992, GÃ¡bor TakÃ¡cs and RÃ³bert Dallos, both then aged 17, were the first people to face legal action after creating a crop circle in Hungary. In 2000, Matthew Williams became the first man in the UK to be arrested for causing criminal damage after making a crop circle near Devizes.

Creation ðŸ”—

Human origin ðŸ”—

The scientific consensus on crop circles is that they are constructed by human beings as hoaxes, advertising, or art. The most widely known method for a person or group to construct a crop formation is to tie one end of a rope to an anchor point and the other end to a board which is used to crush the plants. Bower and Chorley confessed in 1991 to making the first crop circles in southern England. In a copycat effect, increasingly complex circles started appearing in many countries around the world, including fractal figures. Some crop formations are paid for by companies who use them as advertising. Hoaxers have been caught in the process of making new circles, such as in 2004 in the Netherlands.

Natural origins ðŸ”—

Weather ðŸ”—

It has been suggested that crop circles may be the result of extraordinary meteorological phenomena ranging from freak tornadoes to ball lightning, but there is no evidence of any crop circle being created by any of these causes. In 1880, an amateur scientist, John Rand Capron, wrote a letter to the editor of journal Nature about some circles in crops and blamed them on a recent storm. In 1980, Terence Meaden, a meteorologist and physicist, proposed that the circles were caused by whirlwinds whose course was affected by southern England hills.

Animal activity ðŸ”—

In 2009, the attorney general for the island state of Tasmania stated that Australian wallabies had been found creating crop circles in fields of opium poppies.

Alternative explanations ðŸ”—

In science magazines from the 1980s and 1990s, one could read reports suggesting that the plants were bent by something that could be microwave radiation, rather than broken by physical impact.

Paranormal ðŸ”—

Since becoming the focus of widespread media attention in the 1980s, crop circles have been the subject of speculation by various paranormal, ufological, and anomalistic investigators, ranging from proposals that they were created by bizarre meteorological phenomena to messages from extraterrestrial beings. There has also been speculation that crop circles have a relation to ley lines. Some paranormal advocates think that crop circles are caused by ball lightning and that the patterns are so complex that they have to be controlled by some entity. Responding to local beliefs that “extraterrestrial beings” in UFOs were responsible for crop circles appearing, the Indonesian National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN) described crop circles as “man-made”.

Changes to crops ðŸ”—

A small number of scientists (physicist Eltjo Haselhoff, the late biophysicist William Levengood) have claimed to observe differences between the crops inside the circles and outside them, citing this as evidence they were not man made.

Related art ðŸ”—

Patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in snow, by using skis, snow shoes or just walking with ordinary shoes. Patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in sand. Images can be made in forests by cutting trees, especially in areas with snow.

Folklore ðŸ”—

Researchers of crop circles have linked modern crop circles to old folkloric tales to support the claim that they are not artificially produced. Crop circles are culture dependent: they appear mostly in developed and secularised Western countries where people are receptive to New Age beliefs, including Japan, but they do not appear at all in other zones, such as Muslim countries. Fungi can cause circular areas of crop to die, probably the origin of tales of “fairie rings”. A 17th-century English woodcut called the Mowing-Devil depicts the devil with a scythe mowing (cutting) a circular design in a field of oats. In the

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crop_circle

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts ðŸ”—

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected modern cultures, technologies, religions, and human biology. A common idea is that deities from religions are extraterrestrial in origin, with advanced technologies interpreted as divine status by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeological or unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed studies. Some argue that ancient astronaut theories have racist undertones, diminishing the accomplishments of indigenous cultures.

Overview ðŸ”—

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers maintain that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence who landed on Earth in the past. They propose that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that extraterrestrials built structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island or aided humans in their construction. Evidence is drawn from documentary gaps in historical and archaeological records, as well as archaeological artifacts considered anachronistic.

The idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to spread theories of an alternate past, often aligning with white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents portray themselves as an oppressed minority of academics, claiming a conspiracy by ‘big archaeology’ to disenfranchise them. They focus on monumental archaeological structures, implying that non-white Indigenous people could not have built them without extraterrestrial intervention. However, some indigenous voices argue that the idea of extraterrestrials supports their own origin stories.

A common feature in these stories portrays aliens as light-skinned or Aryan, as claimed by Erich von DÃ¤niken. Some proponents are associated with white supremacism, though their theories are sometimes applied to European cultures. Mainstream archaeologists largely ignored these claims until recently, while skeptics universally panned them. Carl Sagan noted that cases of interest have reasonable alternative explanations or are misreported, fabricated, or distorted.

History of Ancient Aliens Beliefs and Their Proponents ðŸ”—

Paleocontact narratives first appeared in early science fiction of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including Edison’s Conquest of Mars (1898) and the works of H.P. Lovecraft. Harold T. Wilkins proposed the idea in earnest in 1954. It gained popularity in the 1960s due to the Space Race and Erich von DÃ¤niken’s works. Critics emerged in the 1970s, discrediting Von DÃ¤niken’s claims. Ufologists separated the idea from the UFO controversy, and by the early 1980s, little support remained.

Shklovskii and Sagan ðŸ”—

Carl Sagan co-authored Intelligent Life in the Universe (1966) with Soviet astrophysicist Iosif Shklovsky. In Broca’s Brain (1979), Sagan suggested that he and Shklovsky might have inspired the wave of 1970s ancient astronaut books, disapproving of “von DÃ¤niken and other uncritical writers” who built on these ideas as valid evidence. Sagan pointed out that many legends, artifacts, and purported out-of-place artifacts cited in support of ancient astronaut hypotheses could be easily explained with more conventional hypotheses. He reiterated that extraterrestrial visits to Earth were possible but unproven and improbable.

Erich von DÃ¤niken ðŸ”—

Erich von DÃ¤niken was a leading proponent in the late 1960s and early 1970s, gaining a large audience through his book Chariots of the Gods? (1968) and its sequels. He argued that certain artifacts required more sophisticated technology than was available to ancient cultures, suggesting they were constructed by extraterrestrial visitors or humans who learned from them. Examples include Stonehenge, Pumapunku, the Moai of Easter Island, the Great Pyramid of Giza, and the ancient Baghdad electric batteries.

Von DÃ¤niken wrote that ancient art and iconography illustrate air and space vehicles, non-human creatures, ancient astronauts, and advanced technology. He stated that geographically separated cultures share artistic themes, implying a common origin. He interpreted the sarcophagus lid of Maya ruler Pacal the Great as a seated astronaut, while the iconography identifies it as a portrait of the ruler with the World Tree of Maya mythology.

He interpreted the origins of religions as reactions to encounters with an alien race, considering their technology supernatural and the aliens themselves as gods. He stated that religious traditions contain references to alien visitors in the way of descriptions of stars and vehicular objects traveling through air and space. One such is Ezekiel’s revelation, which DÃ¤niken interprets as a landing spacecraft.

Von DÃ¤niken’s hypotheses became popularized in the U.S. after the NBC-TV documentary In Search of Ancient Astronauts and the film Chariots of the Gods. Critics argue that von DÃ¤niken misrepresented data, that many of his claims were unfounded, and that none of his core claims have been validated. The Christian creationist community is highly critical of his work.

Regarding the Nazca Lines, von DÃ¤niken stated that they gave him the impression of an airfield. Kenneth L. Feder argues that readers seeing the Nazca Lines for the first time in a book about aliens would be more likely to associate those features with extraterrestrial origins. In 1970, von DÃ¤niken admitted that the Nazca markings “could have been laid out on their gigantic scale by working from a model using a system of coordinates.”

Zecharia Sitchin ðŸ”—

Zecharia Sitchin’s series The Earth Chronicles, beginning with The 12th Planet, revolves around his interpretation of ancient Sumerian and Middle Eastern texts, megalithic sites, and artifacts. He hypothesized that the gods of old Mesopotamia were astronauts from the planet “Nibiru,” which the Sumerians believed to be a remote “12th planet” associated with the god Marduk. According to Sitchin, Nibiru continues to orbit the Sun on a 3,600-year elongated orbit. Modern astronomy has found no evidence to support Sitchin’s ideas.

Sitchin argued that Sumerian texts tell the story that 50 Anunnaki, inhabitants of Nibiru, came to Earth approximately 400,000 years ago to mine raw materials, especially gold. They genetically engineered laborers to work the mines, creating Homo sapiens sapiens: the “Adapa” or Adam of later mythology. Sitchin contended the Anunnaki were active in human affairs until their culture was destroyed by global catastrophes caused by the abrupt end of the last ice age some 12,000 years ago. Sitchin’s work has not received mainstream scholarly support. Semitic languages scholar Michael S. Heiser says that many of Sitchin’s translations are not consistent with Mesopotamian cuneiform bilingual dictionaries.

Alan F. Alford, author of Gods of the New Millennium (1996), was an adherent of the ancient astronaut hypothesis but now finds fault with Sitchin’s hypothesis, stating that the gods personified the falling sky.

Robert Temple ðŸ”—

Robert K. G. Temple’s 1976 book, The Sirius Mystery, argues that the Dogon people of northwestern Mali preserved an account of extraterrestrial visitation from around 5,000 years ago. He quotes evidence, including advanced astronomical knowledge inherited by the tribe, descriptions, and comparative belief systems with ancient civilizations. His work draws heavily on the studies of cultural anthropologists Marcel Griaule and Germaine Dieterlen.

His conclusions have been criticized by scientists, who point out discrepancies within Temple’s account and suggested that the Dogon may have received some of their astronomical information recently from European sources.

UFO Religions ðŸ”—

Various new religious movements, including some branches of Theosophy, Scientology, RaÃ«lism, Aetherius Society, and Heaven’s Gate, believe in ancient and present-day contact with extraterrestrial intelligence. Many of these faiths see both ancient scriptures and recent revelations as connected with the action of aliens from other planetary systems. Psychologists have found that UFO religions have similarities which suggest that members of these groups consciously or subliminally associate enchantment with the memes of science fiction.

Claims of Proponents ðŸ”—

Among scientists, the consensus is that the ancient astronaut hypothesis is not impossible, but unjustified and unnecessary. The “mysteries” cited as evidence can be explained without having to invoke ancient astronauts. Since ancient astronauts are unnecessary, Occam’s razor should be applied and the hypothesis rejected.

Ancient Religious Texts ðŸ”—

Proponents cite ancient mythologies to support their viewpoints, based on the idea that ancient creation myths of gods who descend from the heavens to Earth to create or instruct humanity are representations of alien visitors, whose superior technology accounts for their perception as gods. Proponents draw an analogy to occurrences in modern time when isolated cultures are exposed to advanced technology, such as when, in the early 20th century, “cargo cults” were discovered in the South Pacific.

The ancient Sumerian myth of EnÃ»ma EliÅ¡, inscribed on cuneiform tablets and part of the Library of Ashurbanipal, says humankind was created to

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_astronauts

item.title: Alien Abduction
item.description:
Alien abduction (also called abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction) refers to the phenomenon of people reporting what they believe to be the real experience of being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation.[1] People claiming to have been abducted are usually called “abductees”[2] or “experiencers”. Most scientists and mental health professionals explain these experiences by factors such as suggestibility (e.g. false memory syndrome), sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology.[3] Skeptic Robert Sheaffer sees similarity between some of the aliens described by abductees and those depicted in science fiction films, in particular Invaders From Mars (1953).[4]

Typical claims involve forced medical examinations that emphasize the subject’s reproductive systems.[5] Abductees sometimes claim to have been warned against environmental abuses and the dangers of nuclear weapons,[6] or to have engaged in interspecies breeding.[7] The contents of the abduction narrative often seem to vary with the home culture of the alleged abductee.[4] Unidentified flying objects (UFOs), alien abduction, and mind control plots can also be part of radical political apocalyptic and millenarian narratives.[8]

reference: Alien Abduction

item.title: Extraterrestrials in fiction
item.description:
Fictional Depictions of Extraterrestrial Life ðŸ”—

This article provides an overview of how extraterrestrial life is portrayed in fiction, distinguishing it from claims of actual alien encounters. It notes that the article relies heavily on a limited number of sources and encourages readers to contribute additional citations.

History ðŸ”—

This section traces the evolution of extraterrestrial depictions in fiction from antiquity to modern times.

Antiquity ðŸ”—

This subsection begins with Lucian’s True History (2nd century) as an early example of extraterrestrial encounters, featuring a visit to the Moon. It explains that early concepts of extraterrestrials were closely tied to the understanding of astronomy and the prevailing anthropocentric view, where aliens were essentially humans from other celestial bodies. Voltaire’s MicromÃ©gas (1752) and works by Johannes Kepler, Francis Godwin, and Cyrano de Bergerac are mentioned as examples where extraterrestrials differed from humans only in culture or size.

Early 20th Century ðŸ”—

This subsection discusses the impact of Charles Darwin’s On the Origin of Species (1859) on alien depictions, leading to more diverse and non-humanoid portrayals. Camille Flammarion’s works, H.G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds (1898) and The First Men in the Moon (1901), Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey (1934), and Olaf Stapledon’s Star Maker (1937) are highlighted as examples of genuinely alien lifeforms. It also notes that many works still featured human-like aliens. The War of the Worlds is analyzed for its use of Darwinian evolution, exploration of alien life implications, critique of British imperialism, and introduction of alien invasion tropes.

Early 20th Century ðŸ”—

This section discusses the rise of pulp magazines and their influence on science fiction. It notes the prevalence of quasi-human aliens, monstrous invaders, and the inversion of the alien invasion trope with humans conquering alien worlds. The section also mentions the common setting of stories within the Solar System and the shift brought about by Stanley G. Weinbaum’s A Martian Odyssey, which featured a unique Martian ecosystem.

Modern Times ðŸ”—

This section discusses the evolution of alien depictions in modern times, starting with The Eternaut by HÃ©ctor GermÃ¡n Oesterheld, which critiques imperialism and colonialism through an alien invasion of Buenos Aires. The Barney and Betty Hill incident (1961) is mentioned as the origin of the “grey alien” archetype. The impact of TV and films, particularly Star Trek, Star Wars, and Alien, on popularizing extraterrestrial themes is discussed. The section concludes by noting the influence of computer-generated imagery (CGI) on creating more diverse and bizarre alien lifeforms.

Types ðŸ”—

This section categorizes the various ways extraterrestrials are portrayed in fiction, including their intelligence levels, biological forms, and attitudes towards humanity. It notes that aliens may be hostile invaders, friendly allies, or indifferent observers. The section also mentions that some extraterrestrials may originate from unexplored regions of Earth, such as the sea, sky, underground, or other dimensions.

See Also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of internal links to related Wikipedia articles, including “Parasites in fiction,” “List of fictional extraterrestrials,” “List of films featuring extraterrestrials,” “List of humanoid aliens,” “Mars in fiction,” and “First contact (science fiction).”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, journal articles, and online resources.

Bibliography ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of books used as background material for the article.

Further Reading ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about extraterrestrials in fiction.

External Links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to an external website with additional information on the topic.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrials_in_fiction

item.title: List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
item.description:
List of Alleged Extraterrestrial Beings ðŸ”—

This Wikipedia entry catalogues various extraterrestrial beings reported in close encounters, claimed sightings, or speculated to be associated with unidentified flying objects (UFOs). It clarifies that the term “extraterrestrial being” in this context differs from the biological definition of “alien species” in ecology.

List ðŸ”—

This section presents a table outlining alleged extraterrestrial beings, providing their names, descriptions, and associated events or concepts.

  • Flatwoods Monster: A tall humanoid with a spade-shaped head, linked to the Flatwoods Monster incident.
  • Greys: Grey-skinned humanoids, typically around 1 meter tall, hairless, with large heads and black almond-shaped eyes. They are associated with the Roswell incident and are the most common type of extraterrestrial being reported since the 1960s.
  • Hopkinsville Goblin: Small, greenish-silver humanoids, connected to the Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter.
  • Little Green Men: Diminutive green humanoids, a classic cultural stereotype, though actual abduction reports rarely match this description.
  • Nordic Aliens: Humanoids with stereotypical “Nordic” features (tall, blonde hair, blue eyes). They are sometimes called Space Brothers and include groups like the Plejaren (previously known as Pleiadeans), Venusians, Tall Whites, and Agarthans from Agartha.
  • Cryptozoological Animals and Cryptobotanical Plants: Creatures from folklore, religion, and mythology (e.g., golems, dwarves, giants from Atlantis), as well as reports of ghosts, poltergeists, and time travelers. Examples include the Mothman, Jersey Devil, Loch Ness Monster, Nommo, Mokele-mbembe, Yokai, Quinametzin, Rephaite, and Loveland Frogman. Some believe these creatures are of extraterrestrial or mixed origin, as suggested by the extraterrestrial, interdimensional, or cryptoterrestrial hypotheses.
  • Reptilians and Reptiloids: Tall, scaly humanoids, sometimes linked to ancient astronauts. They include Draconians and Orion reptilian-humanoid matriarchies. David Icke is a prominent advocate of the reptilian conspiracy theory.
  • Rods or Skyfish: Elongated visual artifacts in photos and videos, sometimes claimed to be extraterrestrial beings, but generally believed to be motion blur from flying insects.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of related topics and concepts, categorized as follows:

  • General Concepts: Alien abduction, alien abduction entities, alleged extraterrestrial beings, ancient astronauts, chimera, conspiracy theory, contactees, cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, evolutionary biology, extraterrestrial hypothesis, genetic mutation, horizontal evolution, interdimensional hypothesis, list of conspiracy theories, list of cryptids, list of humanoid aliens, list of occult terms, MUFON (United States), Kosmopoisk (Russia), and New World Order.
  • In Fiction: Fictional biology, lists of fictional alien species, list of fictional extraterrestrials, lists of fictional species, Babylon 5, Battlestar Galactica, List of alien races in DC Comics, List of alien races in Marvel Comics, Mass Effect, Stargate, Star Trek, Star Wars, and The Twilight Zone.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to the original materials. These references support the information presented about each alleged extraterrestrial being and related concepts.

External links ðŸ”—

This section contains links to external resources, such as Susan A. Clancy’s book Abducted: How People Come to Believe They Were Kidnapped by Aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_alleged_extraterrestrial_beings

item.title: Unidentified flying object
item.description:
Unidentified Flying Object (UFO) ðŸ”—

An unidentified flying object (UFO), also known as unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) or unidentified anomalous phenomena, is defined as an object or phenomenon observed in the sky that cannot be immediately identified or explained. While reports of unusual aerial sightings date back to at least the 3rd century BC, the term “UFO” gained prominence after World War II and escalated during the Space Age. Most UFOs are later identified as known objects or atmospheric phenomena, but a small percentage remain unexplained. Government investigations and studies by various organizations have occurred over the years, but without confirmation of claims that UFOs are evidence of extraterrestrial intelligence or other unconventional hypotheses. Skeptics often attribute UFO sightings to natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, or hoaxes. The philosophical implications of UFOs relate to epistemology, dealing with temporarily or permanently unknowable anomalous phenomena. The U.S. government has two entities dedicated to UFO data collection and analysis: NASA’s UAP independent study team and the Department of Defense’s All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office.

Terminology ðŸ”—

During the late 1940s and 1950s, UFOs were commonly referred to as “flying saucers” or “flying discs,” originating from the Kenneth Arnold incident. Captain Edward J. Ruppelt of the USAF coined the acronym “UFO” to replace the misleading term “flying saucer.” The term “unidentified aerial phenomena” (UAP) emerged in the late 1960s and has gained usage in the 21st century due to negative connotations associated with “UFO.” UAP is sometimes expanded to “unidentified anomalous phenomenon.” In popular culture, UFO has become synonymous with alien spacecraft, sometimes referred to as “extra-terrestrial vehicle” (ETV).

Identification ðŸ”—

Most UFOs can be identified as ordinary objects or phenomena after careful investigation. Common identified sources include aircraft, astronomical objects, balloons, hoaxes, light phenomena, other atmospheric objects and phenomena, and psychological effects. The USAF’s 1952â€“1955 study categorized UFOs as balloons, astronomical objects, aircraft, light phenomena, birds, clouds, dust, insufficient information, psychological manifestations, unknown, and other. Allan Hendry, a CUFOS researcher, found that fewer than one percent of cases were hoaxes, with most sightings being misidentifications of prosaic phenomena due to inexperience or misperception. Astronomer Andrew Fraknoi encourages critical thinking when evaluating UFO claims, suggesting that thorough investigation often reveals less to the stories than initially perceived.

History ðŸ”—

Early history before the 20th century ðŸ”—

Throughout history, people have observed unusual sights in the sky, including comets, meteors, planets, planetary conjunctions, and optical phenomena. Halley’s Comet, first recorded by Chinese astronomers, was often seen as a supernatural portent or omen. Some UFO enthusiasts have drawn parallels between religious symbols in medieval paintings and UFO reports, but art historians offer conventional religious interpretations.

Examples of pre-contemporary reports include:

  • Julius Obsequens, a Roman writer, documented wonders and portents in Rome between 249 and 12 BCE, with descriptions resembling meteor showers.
  • Shen Kuo, a Song Chinese scholar-official, described a flying object with opening doors and blinding light in his Dream Pool Essays (1088).
  • A woodcut by Hans Glaser from 1561, known as the “celestial phenomenon over Nuremberg,” has been linked to ancient astronaut claims, though skeptics argue it depicts a sundog.
  • A similar report from 1566 over Basel, along with other leaflets from the 15th and 16th centuries, described “miracles” and “sky spectacles” resembling natural phenomena.
  • In 1878, farmer John Martin reported seeing a large, dark, circular object resembling a saucer, marking one of the first uses of the word “saucer” in association with a UFO.

From November 1896 to April 1897, newspapers reported numerous sightings of “mystery airships,” with some people claiming to have spoken to the pilots. Thomas Edison dismissed these reports as fake.

20th century and after ðŸ”—

During World War II, Allied and Axis pilots reported round, glowing fireballs known as “foo fighters.” Explanations for these sightings included St. Elmo’s fire, the planet Venus, hallucinations, and German secret weapons. In 1946, over 2,000 reports of unidentified aerial objects, referred to as “Russian hail” or “ghost rockets,” were collected, primarily by the Swedish military.

Science fiction depictions of spacecraft similar to flying saucers predated the first widely reported UFO sighting in 1947.

The modern UFO craze began with the Kenneth Arnold sighting on June 24, 1947, when he described seeing “flying saucers” near Mount Rainier. Within weeks, reports of flying saucer sightings became common, including the Roswell incident in 1947. In 1950, influential books by Donald Keyhoe, Frank Scully, and Gerald Heard proposed the extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis.

Media speculation ran rampant, especially during the 1952 UFO scare in Washington, D.C. By 1953, intelligence officials worried that genuine incursions by enemy aircraft could be lost in a flood of UFO reports.

From 1947, the U.S. Air Force began investigating UFO reports through Project Sign, followed by Project Grudge and Project Blue Book. In the late 1950s, public pressure mounted for declassification of UFO records, but the CIA resisted. Official U.S. Air Force interest in UFO reports ended in 1969 after the Condon Report concluded that further investigation was not justified.

From the 1960s to 1990s, UFOs became part of American popular culture’s obsession with the supernatural and paranormal. In 1961, the Barney and Betty Hill alien abduction account gained notoriety. In 1966, 5% of Americans reported seeing something they thought was a “flying saucer.”

In December 2017, media attention increased with the revelation of the secret Advanced Aviation Threat Identification Program, funded from 2007 to 2012. Leaked Pentagon UFO videos led to increased mainstream attention to UFO stories. In July 2021, Harvard astronomer Avi Loeb announced the Galileo Project to seek evidence of extraterrestrial artifacts. Government programs, such as NASA’s UAP independent study team and the All-domain Anomaly Resolution Office, were established to investigate UFO claims more fully. In May 2022, the United States House Intelligence Subcommittee held congressional hearings on UAPs, the first public hearing on UFO sightings in the US in over 50 years. Another Congressional hearing took place on July 26, 2023, featuring the whistleblower claims of former U.S. Air Force officer David Grusch.

Polls have shown varying levels of belief in UFOs among Americans, with some indicating that a significant percentage believe UFOs are evidence of alien life.

UFOs have been taken up by religious studies scholars, and popular culture has played a significant role in shaping public perception of extraterrestrials.

Notable cases and incidents ðŸ”—

Notable cases and incidents include:

Britain ðŸ”—

  • The Rendlesham Forest incident (1980)

France ðŸ”—

  • The Valensole UFO incident (1965)
  • The Trans-en-Provence Case (1981)

United States ðŸ”—

  • The Kecksburg UFO incident (1965)
  • The Travis Walton abduction claim (1975)
  • The Phoenix Lights (1997)

Famous hoaxes ðŸ”—

  • The Maury Island incident
  • George Adamski’s claims of meetings with telepathic aliens
  • Ed Walters’ Gulf Breeze UFO incident (1987)

Investigations of reports ðŸ”—

UFOs have been investigated by governments and academics in various countries. No official government investigation has ever publicly concluded that UFOs are indisputably real, physical objects, extraterrestrial in origin, or of concern to national defense.

Known government studies include the Swedish military’s ghost rockets investigation (1946â€“1947), Project Blue Book by the USAF (1947â€“1969), Project Twinkle investigation into green fireballs (1948â€“1951), Project Blue Book Special Report No. 14 by the Battelle Memorial Institute, and the Brazilian Air Force’s OperaÃ§Ã£o Prato (1977). France has had an ongoing investigation (GEPAN/SEPRA/GEIPAN) since 1977, and Uruguay has had a similar investigation since 1989.

Americas ðŸ”—

Brazil (1952â€“2016) ðŸ”—

The National Archives of Brazil has documentation from the Brazilian Air Force regarding UFO investigations between 1952 and 2016.

Chile (c. 1968) ðŸ”—

The SEFAA (previously CEFAA) began receiving case reports of UFO sightings in Chile in 1968.

Canada (c. 1950) ðŸ”—

The Department of National Defence has dealt with UFO reports and investigations across

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unidentified_flying_object

item.title: Alien Hominid
item.description:
Alien Hominid ðŸ”—

Alien Hominid is a run and gun video game developed by The Behemoth. It initially launched as a Flash game on Newgrounds in 2002, created by Tom Fulp and Dan Paladin. It was later re-released in expanded versions for various consoles and computers.

Developer and Publisher Information ðŸ”—

The game was developed by The Behemoth, with Dan Paladin as the designer and Tom Fulp as the programmer. Matthew E. Harwood composed the music. The original Flash version was released in 2002. Console versions were released in 2004 and 2005 for PlayStation 2, GameCube, and Xbox. A Game Boy Advance port, developed by Tuna Technologies, came out in 2006. A high-definition version, Alien Hominid HD, was released for Xbox 360 in 2007. A remaster, also titled Alien Hominid HD, was released in 2023 for Windows, Nintendo Switch, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X/S, alongside a sequel, Alien Hominid Invasion. A PlayStation 4 and PlayStation 5 version is planned.

Gameplay ðŸ”—

Alien Hominid is a side-scrolling run and gun shooter, similar to Metal Slug. Gameplay involves instant death upon being hit and supports two-player simultaneous play. Players control the Alien Hominid, who defends against waves of secret agents using a blaster, melee attacks, and grenades. Advanced moves include rolling, biting off heads, digging underground, and collecting power-ups for extra grenades, shields, and unique ammo. Players can also drive vehicles, ride a Yeti, and pilot a UFO. Completing tasks unlocks hats for the Hominid. The main game has sixteen stages. Additional modes include Challenge, Neutron Ball, Pinata Boss, a PDA game with 200 levels and a level editor, All You Can Eat, and the Super Soviet Missile Mastar minigame.

Plot ðŸ”—

The Alien Hominid is flying over Earth when the FBI intercepts its spacecraft, causing it to crash. The FBI steals the ship, leading the alien to pursue them with the help of “fat kids.” After retrieving the ship, the alien crashes into Russia due to a Soviet missile. The alien recovers the ship again but is captured by an Area 51 spaceship. The alien escapes, befriends a sentient eyeball, and defeats a buff alien. The “fat kids” help the alien and eyeball escape in the ship, using a tractor beam to lift the kids out of an Area 51 truck.

Reception ðŸ”—

The game received generally favorable reviews on most platforms, with the Game Boy Advance version receiving universal acclaim. Reviewers praised its old-school gameplay, difficulty, and humor. GameSpot nominated it for “Funniest Game” in 2004.

Legacy ðŸ”—

The Hominid appears in The Behemoth’s Castle Crashers and is a playable character in Super Meat Boy. The Super Soviet Missile Mastar minigame was released as a free iOS app in 2011, and an improved version of the PDA Games minigame was released for iOS in 2011. Tom Fulp cited the PDA Games as inspiration for BattleBlock Theater.

Notes ðŸ”—

Tuna Technologies ported the game to Game Boy Advance and J2ME. Zoo Digital Publishing and O3 Entertainment published the PlayStation 2, GameCube, Xbox, and Game Boy Advance versions in Europe and North America, respectively. Allister Brimble and Anthony N. Putson composed the Game Boy Advance music.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Hominid

item.title: Allianceâ€“Union universe
item.description:
Allianceâ€“Union Universe ðŸ”—

This article provides an overview of the Allianceâ€“Union universe, a fictional setting created by C. J. Cherryh for her science fiction novels and short stories. It details the universe’s history, key factions, technologies, and alien species.

Description ðŸ”—

This section introduces the Allianceâ€“Union universe as a future history spanning the third and fourth millennia, focusing on humanity’s expansion into space. It identifies the three major economic and political powers: Earth Company, the Alliance (a confederation of interstellar trade merchants), and the Union (a breakaway government based on Cyteen). The section highlights the Company Wars, Earth Company’s failed attempts to control space expansion, and the Union’s use of cloned humans (azi) in its quest for territory. It also mentions that the Allianceâ€“Union universe includes other series like Faded Sun, Chanur, Morgaine, and Merovingen Nights. Patricia Monk’s concept of a “megatext” or “collage novel” is introduced, suggesting that linking these series creates a larger, interconnected narrative.

History ðŸ”—

This section outlines the chronological development of the Allianceâ€“Union universe. It begins with the establishment of space stations by the Earth Company and the emergence of distinct stationer and merchanter cultures. The discovery of Pell’s World in the Tau Ceti system, with its hospitable environment and alien life (the Hisa), disrupts the existing power balance. The development of faster-than-light (FTL) travel leads to Earth’s attempts to reassert control, culminating in the Company Wars. The Union, centered at the Cyteen system, declares independence and uses genetically engineered clones (azi) in its military. The conflict reaches a turning point at Pell Station, leading to the formation of the Alliance as a neutral power. Conrad Mazian, commander of the Earth Company Fleet, refuses to accept peace and becomes a renegade. Signy Mallory, one of his captains, defects to the Alliance. The Mazianni are eventually driven off, but a new rivalry emerges between the Alliance and Union. The section concludes by mentioning the political factions within Union and the role of scientist Ariane Emory.

Genre ðŸ”—

This section classifies the various works within the Allianceâ€“Union universe by genre. Many stories set in space are considered space opera, while those on planets are planetary romances. Works like Cyteen and Downbelow Station are also hard science fiction. The “Company Wars” novels and the Faded Sun trilogy are military science fiction. The Merovingen Nights series is classified as science fantasy, and The Morgaine Cycle books are set remotely in time and space. Voyager in Night incorporates elements of horror fiction.

Books and Reading Order ðŸ”—

This section provides guidance on the order in which to read the books set in the Allianceâ€“Union universe. C. J. Cherryh states that most books can be read in any order, with two exceptions: Heavy Time and Hellburner should be read in that order, and Cyteen and Regenesis should be read in sequence. The novels in the Faded Sun, Chanur, and Morgaine series are also designed to be read in order. The Merovingen Nights series begins with Angel with the Sword and continues with the short story anthologies.

Major Characters ðŸ”—

This section lists and describes some of the most important characters in the Allianceâ€“Union universe. These include:

  • Pyanfar Chanur: Hani captain and leader of the Compact.
  • Sten Duncan: Alliance soldier who joins the Mri.
  • Ariane Emory-1 and Ariane Emory-2 PR: Scientist and her clone from Cyteen.
  • Damon Konstantin and Elene Quen: Leaders of Pell Station and the Merchanter Alliance.
  • Conrad Mazian: Commander of the Earth Company Fleet and later leader of the Mazianni.
  • Signy Mallory: Captain of the Norway who defects to the Alliance.
  • Elizabeth McGee: Union scientist.
  • James Robert Neihart: Senior captain of Finity’s End.
  • Kurt Morgan: Survivor of the Endymion.
  • Raen a Sul hant Meth-maren: Human mediator with the Majat.
  • Thorn: Human raised by the Shonunin.

Sentient Alien Species ðŸ”—

This section provides a table listing various sentient alien species encountered in the Allianceâ€“Union universe. The table includes the species name, home system, home planet, the works in which they appear, and brief notes about their characteristics. Some of the species listed are the Amaut, Ahnit, Caliban, Chi, Elee, Hani, Hisa, Iduve, Kallia, Kif, Knnn, Majat, Mahendo’sat, Mri, Nemet, Regul, Stsho, Sharrh, Shonunin, and Tc’a. The section also mentions the Qual/Khal from the Morgaine books and the Harilim.

Planets ðŸ”—

This section describes several key planets in the Allianceâ€“Union universe:

  • Pell’s World (Downbelow): A planet orbiting Tau Ceti, notable for its advanced ecosystem, intelligent extraterrestrial life (the Hisa), and its impact on the balance of power.
  • Gehenna: A habitable planet in the Zeta Reticuli system, secretly colonized by the Union and home to the calibans.
  • Cyteen: A planet deep in Union territory, with a toxic atmosphere and native life, known for its rejuvenation drug.
  • Merovin: An isolated planet with backward technology due to poor interstellar relations.

Technologies ðŸ”—

This section outlines the signature futuristic technologies of the Allianceâ€“Union universe:

  • Jump Drive: Allows faster-than-light travel by shifting ships into a parallel space.
  • Rejuv: A life-extension drug derived from Cyteen’s lifeforms.
  • Human Cloning: Used extensively by the Union to create azi, genetically tailored laborers and soldiers.
  • Tape: Subliminal conditioning and information transfer used for various purposes.
  • Terraforming: Technologies used to make areas of Cyteen suitable for Earth-based life.

Society ðŸ”—

This section describes the societal structures and attitudes within the Allianceâ€“Union universe. It highlights the divergence of attitudes between planet-dwellers, space station-dwellers, and starship crews. Space station residents are cautious, while starship crews have an insular worldview due to the effects of jump. In Union, there is a division between unengineered citizens (CITs) and azi.

Mazianni ðŸ”—

This section defines the Mazianni as the military starships and their crews who remained loyal to Conrad Mazian after he renounced his allegiance to Earth. It describes their origins as the Earth Company Fleet, their role in the Company War, and their subsequent guerrilla warfare.

Songs ðŸ”—

This section mentions that C. J. Cherryh wrote a collection of songs about the station trade, which were recorded by filk musician Leslie Fish and released on an album entitled Finity’s End.

Critical Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception of the Allianceâ€“Union universe. John Clute called it Cherryh’s “central achievement,” noting its rough edges but the impression of a larger, yet-to-be-revealed history. M. Keith Booker described it as “so far-reaching that its overall outlines remain unclear and continue to develop.”

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the references cited in the article.

Works Cited ðŸ”—

This section lists the works cited in the article.

Further Reading ðŸ”—

This section lists additional resources for further reading about the Allianceâ€“Union universe.

External Links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external websites related to the Allianceâ€“Union universe, including the author’s official site, star maps, and a list of ships.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hisa_(fictional_alien_species)

item.title: Ashtar (extraterrestrial being)
item.description:
Ashtar (Extraterrestrial Being) ðŸ”—

Ashtar, sometimes referred to as Ashtar Sheran, is the name attributed to an alleged extraterrestrial being or group of beings that some individuals claim to have channeled. The first claim of receiving an Ashtar message came from UFO contactee George Van Tassel in 1952. Following Van Tassel’s claims, numerous other mediums also asserted contact, presenting conflicting messages. Ashtar is often depicted as a humanoid with blond hair and European features, leading to associations with Nordic aliens. The Ashtar movement is studied as a prominent form of UFO religion. The Czech Universe People, for example, venerate Ashtar alongside figures like Jesus and Krishna.

History ðŸ”—

This section provides background information and details the development of the Ashtar phenomenon.

Background ðŸ”—

The concept of Ascended Masters from esoteric teachings reappearing in spacesuits is discussed in the context of UFO religions. Theosophy, particularly Helena Blavatsky’s The Secret Doctrine, is mentioned as containing references to extraterrestrial masters. The term “ashtar” itself appears in Blavatsky’s work, referring to the Sanskrit term ashtar-vidya, meaning advanced warfare technology.

Purported contact with Van Tassel ðŸ”—

George Van Tassel’s claim of telepathic communication with Ashtar in 1952 is detailed. Van Tassel interpreted the Bible in terms of extraterrestrial intervention and claimed Jesus was a being from space. He asserted that humans could tap into the “Universal Mind of God” and receive messages from Ashtar and deceased individuals like Nikola Tesla. From Tesla, he claimed to receive instructions to build the Integratron, a machine to extend lifespan and access knowledge.

Van Tassel’s early messages from Ashtar focused on apocalyptic concerns regarding the hydrogen bomb. It was claimed that Ashtar, as Commander in Chief of the Ashtar Galactic Command, entered the Solar System to warn humanity about the dangers of nuclear detonation. The messages stated the space command was determined to prevent Earth’s destruction and was assisting the human race. Van Tassel claimed to have been tasked with delivering specific messages to the U.S. federal government.

Van Tassel claimed his communication method involved a new form of telepathy utilizing both human abilities and advanced alien technology, rather than traditional spiritual mediumship.

Giant Rock Space Conventions ðŸ”—

Van Tassel held weekly channeling sessions at Giant Rock, California, where people could ask questions and channel answers from extraterrestrials. These gatherings helped coalesce the contactee subculture. The annual Giant Rock Spacecraft Convention, organized by Van Tassel, began in 1953 and continued for at least 24 years. These conventions attracted thousands of attendees and featured channeled messages from space. Many well-known UFO contactees attended as speakers and channelers.

Ashtar Command ðŸ”—

The concept of an “Ashtar Command” was appropriated by various contactees and channelers, based on Van Tassel’s Ashtar figure. Robert Short, editor of Interplanetary News Digest, popularized the messages but later formed his own group called “Ashtar Command” due to disagreements with Van Tassel. By the mid-1950s, the idea of Ashtar and a galactic law enforcement agency preparing to rescue humanity was established. Elouise Moeller and Adelaide J. Brown made predictions about space fleets and flourishing civilizations on other planets. The failure of these predictions negatively impacted the movement due to a lack of central authority.

Development into spiritual religion (1990s onward) ðŸ”—

The Ashtar message evolved from a technological communication to a more spiritual message, with Ashtar taking on the role of an Ascended Master. The Ashtar Command became a diffuse New Age Spiritualist movement with varied teachings. Tuella founded Guardian Action International. Andreas Grunschloss describes much of the Ashtar channeling as akin to cargo cults, blending spiritual ascension with alien technologies. Millenarian concepts involved a transformation of humans via these technologies, who would then return to Earth to enjoy a golden millennium. Later, teachings were modified to include a less material and more spiritual emphasis.

1970s broadcasts ðŸ”—

In 1971, a British radio talk show received a call-in claiming to originate from outer space. This was followed by the 1977 Southern Television broadcast interruption, when a voice calling itself “Vrillon” of the Ashtar Galactic Command temporarily took over a television transmitter in southern England.

1986 prediction of 1994 apocalypse ðŸ”—

Yvonne Cole, who claimed to channel Ashtar messages from 1986, predicted the destruction of Earth civilizations and the arrival of alien cultures in 1994. Cole claimed governments were working with extraterrestrials to prepare for contact. The landing would be broadcast globally and include a message from the Ashtar Command. These prophecies furthered the fracturing and disappointment within the movement when they failed to occur.

The 1994 Pioneer Voyage meditations ðŸ”—

In 1994, a group of Ashtar Command members claimed to have experienced “the lift-off experience,” being placed aboard “ships of Light” circling the planet. A second event was predicted for December 1994, involving over 250 people, which was declared to have “opened a portal to the AC (Ashtar Command) ships for ever.” Participants were said to have their vibrations raised through a contemplative procedure, and the Pioneer Voyage would occur during meditation. This evoked “memory recall” from members who began providing accounts of their “time aboard the ships.” The group claims the purpose of the lift-off is for the ascension of the human race, aided by electronic grids deployed around the planet by guardian ships.

Developments after the mid-1990s ðŸ”—

By the mid-1990s, channeling groups began using the Internet to unify the movement and establish an authoritative source for Ashtar messages. This addressed the problem of conflicting prophecies and enabled the Ashtar Command to produce a single Ashtar worldview. Channelers espousing messages focusing on destruction, conspiracies, and fear-mongering were declared invalid, claiming they had been deceived by negative space beings. The movement declared that future channels would only be accepted if they operated on the “level of the soul.” Channeled messages would be accepted if they complied with a set of twelve guidelines. The new framework claimed that spaceships would not interfere on Earth unless there was a serious problem. The emergent group was more spiritually focused and less concerned with spaceships. The Pioneer Voyage was incorporated into the Ashtar worldview.

Credibility ðŸ”—

This section discusses the credibility of the Ashtar claims.

The failure of the July 1952 prediction that life on Earth would be destroyed by the hydrogen atom is noted. However, the message also stated that Ashtar was intervening to stop the destruction. After the explosion, messages claimed that Ashtar’s space fleet took actions to repair damage. The Ashtar belief system is based on faith in an extraterrestrial celebrity, and shifts in content seem due to failed prophecy, moving the emphasis from a physical space fleet to the concept of an Ascended Master aiding spiritual advancement. The Ashtar beliefs are seen as a syncretism between the I AM movements and the UFO experience. Though followers believe in Ashtar’s divine right and knowledge, he and others have yet to provide any physical evidence of their existence.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashtar_(extraterrestrial_being)

item.title: Extraterrestrial UFO hypothesis
item.description:
Extraterrestrial UFO Hypothesis ðŸ”—

This article discusses the extraterrestrial hypothesis (ETH), which suggests that some unidentified flying objects (UFOs) are best explained as physical spacecraft occupied by intelligent extraterrestrial organisms or probes designed by them.

Usage of the Term ðŸ”—

This section traces the use of the term “extraterrestrial hypothesis” in UFO literature back to the 1960s. Key figures mentioned include French ufologist Jacques VallÃ©e, who used the term in his 1966 book, and French engineer AimÃ© Michel. James E. McDonald and James Harder also used the term in 1968, including during testimony before Congress. Skeptic Philip J. Klass used it in his 1968 book. Physicist Edward Condon is credited with popularizing the term and its abbreviation “ETH” in 1969 when presenting the findings of the Condon Report.

Chronology ðŸ”—

This section explores the historical roots of the ETH, tracing it back to earlier concepts such as Percival Lowell’s ideas about Martian canals and civilizations, the science fiction writings of H. G. Wells and Edgar Rice Burroughs, and the works of Emanuel Swedenborg, who linked other worlds to the afterlife. It also mentions Charles Fort, who collected accounts of anomalous aerial phenomena in the early 20th century and theorized about visitors from other worlds. The modern ETH took root in the late 1940s and 1950s, influenced by pseudoscience and popular culture, and bolstered by unexplained sightings investigated by governments and civilian groups like NICAP and APRO.

Historical Reports of Extraterrestrial Visits ðŸ”—

This section provides examples of early speculation about extraterrestrial visitors. It mentions a story from 1864 about American geologists discovering an alien-like creature inside an egg-shaped structure. It also discusses H. G. Wells’ The War of the Worlds and the “mystery airships” reported in the late 19th century, with some speculating they were from Mars. The section also notes the influence of comic strips, radio, and movie serials like Buck Rogers and Flash Gordon on popularizing the idea of alien visitation in spaceships. The 1938 radio broadcast of The War of the Worlds by Orson Welles is mentioned as creating public panic.

The 1947 Flying Saucer Wave in America ðŸ”—

This section focuses on the events following Kenneth Arnold’s sighting of unidentified disk-shaped aircraft near Mount Rainier in June 1947. It notes that Arnold quickly considered the possibility of the objects being extraterrestrial. The section mentions the speculation in newspapers about the nature of the objects, including comments from U.S. Senator Glen Taylor and R. DeWitt Miller. It also references Charles Fort’s earlier documentation of unidentified flying objects. The section highlights that most people were initially unwilling to conclude the objects were extraterrestrial, with theories such as secret military projects, Russian spy devices, hoaxes, optical illusions, and mass hysteria being more popular. It cites a Gallup poll from August 1947 showing that most people either had no opinion or believed in a mundane explanation.

Evolution of Public Opinion ðŸ”—

This section examines how public opinion on UFOs and the ETH evolved. It mentions the release of several movies in the early 1950s depicting flying saucers and aliens. It cites a Popular Science poll from 1951 indicating that most UFO witnesses believed they had seen man-made aircraft, while only a small percentage believed they had seen an alien craft. By 1957, a quarter of Americans were willing to believe in the ETH. A Roper poll in 2002 reported that a majority of respondents thought UFOs were real, with nearly half believing they had visited Earth.

Religion ðŸ”—

This section briefly mentions the connection between UFOs and religion, citing the Aetherius Society founded by George King in 1955 as one of the first and most enduring UFO cults.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section discusses NASA’s evolving stance on UAPs. It mentions that in June 2021, NASA Administrator Bill Nelson directed NASA scientists to investigate Unidentified Aerial Phenomenon and explored the possibility that UAP could represent extraterrestrial technology. NASA scientist Ravi Kopparapu advocates studying UAP using scientific methods. Kopparapu presented a paper in August 2021 that supported ETH.

Private or Government Studies ðŸ”—

This section details private and governmental studies that have supported the ETH or had members who dissented from official conclusions. It mentions a 1948 USAF Europe document citing Swedish air intelligence’s conclusion that some UFOs had extraterrestrial origins. It also discusses the USAF Project Sign’s Top Secret Estimate of the Situation in 1948, which concluded that the ETH was the most likely explanation for unexplained cases, but was ordered destroyed. A secret West German study from 1951 to 1954, headed by Hermann Oberth, also concluded that UFOs were extraterrestrial. The CIA’s internal review of UFOs is mentioned, with some scientists considering the ETH. The section also notes individuals within Project Blue Book, such as Major Dewey Fournet and consultant J. Allen Hynek, who supported the ETH. Statements from former CIA Director Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter and Greek physicist Paul Santorini are included. The section also mentions the COMETA report, and Jean-Jacques Velasco’s book.

Critical Responses and Positions of the ETH ðŸ”—

This section presents critical responses to the ETH. It states that there is no scientific proof to back up assertions of alien presence on Earth. It notes that no rigorous analysis has ever concluded that UFO sightings are verifiable evidence for the ETH.

U.S. Military Investigation and Debunkery ðŸ”—

This section discusses the U.S. military’s involvement in investigating and debunking UFOs. It mentions the Army Air Forces Intelligence’s secret study of saucer reports in 1947 and the formation of Project Sign. It notes that Project Sign concluded without endorsing any unified explanation, and the ETH was rejected by USAF Chief of Staff General Hoyt Vandenberg. The CIA’s Office of Scientific Investigation took interest in UFOs following the 1952 UFO flap. The Robertson Panel, organized by the CIA in 1953, reviewed Blue Book’s evidence and recommended a policy of public debunkery.

Involvement of Scientists ðŸ”—

This section highlights the scientific community’s lack of support for the ETH. It mentions Stephen Hawking’s skepticism and quotes Carl Sagan’s warning against self-deception in accepting or rejecting the idea of extraterrestrial visitation. It also quotes Peter A. Sturrock’s call for examining other possible theories beyond the ETH. The section presents the results of Sturrock’s polls of American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics and American Astronomical Society members, showing limited support for the ETH. It summarizes J. Allen Hynek’s seven key reasons for not accepting the ETH, including the failure of surveillance systems to detect UFOs, gravitational and atmospheric considerations, statistical considerations, the behavior of UFOs and their occupants, the isolation of the UFO phenomenon, the space unworthiness of UFOs, and the problem of astronomical distances.

Fewer Sightings Despite Camera Phone Technology ðŸ”—

This section notes that the proliferation of smartphone camera technology has not led to a significant increase in recorded UFO sightings, which has called into question the claimed phenomenology of UFOs.

NASA ðŸ”—

This section states NASA’s official position as of 2006, which is that the ETH lacks empirical evidence. It quotes David Morrison’s statements that no one has ever found a single artifact or convincing evidence for alien visits.

CIA ðŸ”—

This section mentions the CIA’s organization of the Robertson Panel in 1953 to debunk the data collected by Project Blue Book.

Official White House Position ðŸ”—

This section presents the White House’s official response in November 2011 to petitions asking the U.S. government to acknowledge alien visits and disclose any withholding of government interactions with extraterrestrial beings. The response states that the U.S. government has no evidence of life outside our planet or that an extraterrestrial presence has contacted or engaged any member of the human race.

Counter Critique of the Official Position: Conspiracy Theories ðŸ”—

This section discusses the concept of a conspiracy of silence or official cover-up to conceal information about UFOs. It mentions James Harder’s argument in 1968 that significant evidence existed to prove UFOs but had been suppressed. It cites a 1971 survey showing that more Americans believed the government was concealing information about UFOs than believed in the existence of UFOs or the ETH itself. It also mentions comments from former NASA astronauts Gordon Cooper and Brian O’Leary about NASA and the government suppressing UFO sightings.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_UFO_hypothesis

item.title: The Roswell Incident (1980 book)
item.description:
The Roswell Incident (1980 book) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the 1980 book The Roswell Incident by Charles Berlitz and William Moore, which significantly contributed to popularizing the Roswell incident.

Background ðŸ”—

This section provides context for the Roswell incident, starting with the events of 1947.

Events of 1947 ðŸ”—

This subsection details the initial reports surrounding the Roswell incident. It mentions the flying disc craze of 1947, Kenneth Arnold’s sighting, and the Roswell Army Air Field’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc,” which was quickly retracted and replaced with the explanation of a weather balloon.

Roswell revisited ðŸ”—

This part highlights the renewed interest in the Roswell story in 1978, sparked by an interview with retired lieutenant colonel Jesse Marcel, who claimed the debris he retrieved was of extraterrestrial origin. Stanton Friedman, a ufologist, conducted the interview.

Authors ðŸ”—

This section provides background information on the authors of the book. Charles Berlitz is noted for authoring The Bermuda Triangle, a bestseller that popularized the mysteries surrounding that area. William L. Moore is identified as a UFO researcher. Their previous collaboration, The Philadelphia Experiment: Project Invisibility, is also mentioned.

Contents ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the book’s central argument: that an extraterrestrial craft crashed in New Mexico while observing nuclear weapons activity, and the US government engaged in a cover-up. It mentions accounts of debris described as “nothing made on this earth” by Jesse Marcel. Other individuals mentioned include Bill Brazel, Floyd Proctor, and Walt Whitman Jr. The book is described as “version 1” of the Roswell myth. It also introduces the idea that the debris shown in photos with Marcel was substituted as part of the cover-up and that the press was not allowed to closely inspect the recovered material. The authors claimed to have interviewed over 90 witnesses, but only a fraction of their testimonies appear in the book. The incarceration of Mac Brazel is also mentioned. The section notes that Marcel’s narrative was elevated above that of Cavitt, whose description of the debris contradicted Marcel’s account.

Alien bodies ðŸ”—

This section discusses the book’s introduction of the “alien bodies” narrative. It mentions the second-hand stories of Grady “Barney” Barnett and archaeology students encountering wreckage and “alien bodies” on the Plains of San Agustin, far from the initial Roswell crash site. It also points out that some accounts of the Roswell incident contain information from the Aztec, New Mexico, UFO incident, a hoax promoted by Frank Scully.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section notes that critics have deemed The Roswell Incident as “a collection of wild hearsay” and that the book “did not make the commercial impact its authors hoped.” It also mentions that fingers were pointed at Moore when critics and skeptics characterized the Majestic 12 documents as fraudulent.

Aftermath ðŸ”—

This section mentions that William Moore claimed to have engaged in “disinformation” activities against Paul Bennewitz on behalf of the Air Force Office of Special Investigations at a 1989 MUFON conference.

Modern views ðŸ”—

This section references the 1993 inquiry from US congressman Steven Schiff, which led to a General Accounting Office investigation and an Air Force report. The 1994 Air Force report concluded that the material recovered was likely debris from Project Mogul, a military surveillance program using high-altitude balloons.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Roswell_Incident_(1980_book)

item.title: UFO sightings in the United States
item.description:
List of Alleged UFO Sightings in the United States ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive list of alleged UFO sightings in the United States, presented in a tabular format. Each entry includes the date, city, state, a link to a main article if available, and a brief description of the event.

Table of Sightings ðŸ”—

The table is the core of the article, detailing numerous alleged UFO sightings across the United States from 1865 to 2023. Key information includes:

  • September 1865, Cadotte Pass, Montana: Trapper James Lumley reported a craft crash with sulfur smells and hieroglyphics.
  • 1896-1897, Multiple Locations: Sightings of “mystery airships” across the US.
  • April 17, 1897, Aurora, Texas: Residents claimed an airship crashed, and the alien pilot was buried in the local cemetery.
  • February 24, 1942, Los Angeles, California: The “Battle of Los Angeles,” initially thought to be an enemy attack, later attributed to “war nerves” and a weather balloon. Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox called it a “false alarm.”
  • August 1945, Jornada del Muerto, New Mexico: Two boys reported an “avocado-shaped” object crashing with insect-like alien creatures. This is known as the Trinity UFO Case.
  • June 21, 1947, Maury Island, Washington: An incident reported before the Kenneth Arnold sighting, involving alleged encounters with “men in black.”
  • June 24, 1947, Mount Rainier, Washington: Kenneth Arnold reported seeing nine unusual objects flying in formation, describing them as “erratic” and moving at “tremendous speed.”
  • July 1947, Roswell, New Mexico: The Roswell UFO Incident, involving the recovery of materials that became the subject of intense speculation. The US military claims it was a research balloon, while ufologists believe it was an alien craft.
  • January 7, 1948, Maysville, Kentucky: The Mantell Incident, where Captain Thomas F. Mantell, a Kentucky Air National Guard pilot, crashed and died while pursuing a UFO.
  • July 24, 1948, Montgomery, Alabama: The Chiles-Whitted UFO Encounter, where two commercial pilots reported their Douglas DC-3 nearly collided with a strange torpedo-shaped object.
  • October 1, 1948, Fargo, North Dakota: The Gorman Dogfight, where a US Air Force pilot sighted and pursued a UFO for 27 minutes.
  • May 11, 1950, McMinnville, Oregon: The McMinnville UFO photographs, taken by Paul and Evelyn Trent.
  • May 29, 1950, Mount Vernon, Maryland: Captain Willis Sperry and crew reported a “brilliant, diffused, bluish light.”
  • August 15, 1950, Great Falls, Montana: The Mariana UFO incident, which garnered national media attention.
  • August 25, 1951, Lubbock, Texas: The Lubbock Lights, a V-shaped formation of lights seen over the town.
  • May 24, 1952, Burbank, California: Orfeo Angelucci claimed to encounter flying saucers and friendly pilots.
  • July 13, 1952, Washington, D.C.: The 1952 Washington D.C. UFO incident, a series of unidentified flying object reports.
  • September 12, 1952, Flatwoods, West Virginia: Six boys and a woman reported a UFO landing and a bizarre-looking creature, known as the Flatwoods monster.
  • November 23, 1953, Sault Ste. Marie, Michigan: Felix Moncla, Jr., a US Air Force pilot, disappeared with 2nd Lt. Robert Wilson while pursuing a UFO over Lake Superior.
  • November 2, 1957, Levelland, Texas: The Levelland UFO case, where multiple residents reported seeing a UFO.
  • September 19, 1961, Lancaster, New Hampshire: Betty and Barney Hill claimed to have been abducted by extraterrestrials, known as the Hill Abduction.
  • April 24, 1964, Socorro, New Mexico: Lonnie Zamora, a New Mexico police officer, reported a UFO close encounter.
  • September 3, 1965, Exeter, New Hampshire: The Exeter incident, where a large UFO was seen by a teenager and two police officers.
  • December 9, 1965, Kecksburg, Pennsylvania: The Kecksburg UFO incident, where a large fireball was seen, and metal debris was reported.
  • 1969, Leary, Georgia: Jimmy Carter claimed to have seen a UFO.
  • October 11, 1973, Pascagoula, Mississippi: The Pascagoula Abduction, where Charles Hickson and Calvin Parker claimed to have been abducted by aliens.
  • January 12, 1975, North Bergen, New Jersey: The Stonehenge incident, reported near the Stonehenge apartment building.
  • November 5, 1975, Snowflake, Arizona: Travis Walton claimed to have been abducted by a UFO.
  • December 17, 1977, Council Bluffs, Iowa: Residents reported a reddish fireball and a grass fire with molten metal.
  • August 27, 1979, Stephen, Minnesota: The Val Johnson incident, where Deputy Sheriff Val Johnson’s patrol car was struck by a ball of light.
  • December 29, 1980, Dayton, Texas: The Cash-Landrum Incident, where witnesses claimed health damage after a UFO sighting.
  • November 11, 1987, Gulf Breeze, Florida: The Gulf Breeze UFO incident.
  • March 8, 1994, Multiple Locations, Michigan: Over 100 witnesses reported multiple objects across West Michigan, known as the 1994 Lake Michigan UFO event.
  • March 13, 1997, Phoenix, Arizona: The Phoenix Lights, a series of optical phenomena seen by thousands. Former Arizona governor Fife Symington admitted to seeing a delta-shaped craft.
  • January 5, 2000, Highland, Illinois: The “St. Clair Triangle” sighting, where police officers and other witnesses reported a massive, silent, triangular aircraft.
  • August 21, 2004, Chicago, Illinois: A triangular formation of reddish lights was seen by hundreds of witnesses.
  • November 7, 2006, Chicago, Illinois: The Chicago O’Hare UFO sighting, where airport employees witnessed a metallic, saucer-shaped craft.
  • January 5, 2009, Morristown, New Jersey: Five unidentified red objects were seen, later revealed to be a hoax by Joe Rudy and Chris Russo.
  • February 19, 2018, Desert, Arizona: Commercial pilots saw an unidentified object, likely a “high-altitude research balloon.”
  • February 21, 2021, Clayton, New Mexico: A pilot reported seeing a long cylindrical object.
  • February 10, 2023, Deadhorse, Alaska: A high-altitude object was shot down by the U.S. Air Force.
  • February 12, 2023, Lake Huron, Michigan: An octagonal object was shot down by the US Air Force.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides links to related Wikipedia articles:

  • List of reported UFO sightings
  • Psychological perspectives on UFO belief

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources cited in the article, providing links to external websites, news articles, and books that support the information presented in the table.

External links ðŸ”—

This section is currently empty, but it is intended to provide links to external resources related to UFO sightings in the United States.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_sightings_in_the_United_States

It also includes links to lists of legendary creatures, theological beings, and related topics like fictional technology and themes in science fiction.

item.title: Dover Demon
item.description:
Dover Demon ðŸ”—

The Dover Demon is a cryptid reportedly sighted in Dover, Massachusetts, in April 1977.

Sightings ðŸ”—

This section details the reported sightings of the Dover Demon in April 1977. William “Bill” Bartlett, John Baxter, and Abby Brabham, all teenagers at the time, independently reported seeing a strange creature. Bartlett described it as about 4 feet tall with glowing orange eyes and no nose or mouth, with a watermelon-shaped head, perched on a broken stone wall on Farm Street. Baxter reported a similar sighting on Miller Hill Road the same evening, and Brabham claimed to have seen the creature the following night on Springdale Avenue. The teenagers drew sketches of the creature, with Bartlett swearing on a stack of Bibles to the accuracy of his depiction. The locations of the sightings, when plotted on a map, formed a straight line over 2 miles. The sightings became public in May, drawing comparisons to the creatures involved in the Kellyâ€“Hopkinsville encounter of 1955. The Mutual UFO Network also investigated the sightings.

Possible explanations ðŸ”—

This section explores potential explanations for the Dover Demon sightings. One suggestion is that the creature was a foal or a moose calf. Skeptic Joe Nickell proposes that the creature was likely a snowy owl, citing its size, plumage, and the reflection of yellow headlights in its eyes, creating the peach color described by Bartlett. Nickell also suggests that the “long spindly arms” could have been the partially opened wings of an owl. Police suggested the sightings were a hoax. Ben Radford suggests the sightings may have been influenced by the release of Star Wars and Close Encounters of the Third Kind in 1977.

In popular culture ðŸ”—

This section outlines the Dover Demon’s appearances in popular culture. It was featured in an episode of the American horror television series Lost Tapes on Animal Planet in 2009. The Dover Demon appears as a character in the comic book series Proof, where it can see into the future, and in The Perhapanauts. It also made appearances in The Pound: Ghouls Night Out and Hack/Slash: Entry Wound. A Dover Demon appears in the webcomic Gunnerkrigg Court. In the manga series Dandadan, an alien known as Dover Demon takes the form of a bipedal crustacean-like alien with the ability to transform into a stronger form resembling that of a mantis shrimp.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dover_Demon

item.title: Test Tube Aliens
item.description:
Test Tube Aliens ðŸ”—

This entry discusses the Test Tube Aliens toy line, detailing its backstory, the toy’s features, how it functions, and providing references and external links.

Story ðŸ”—

The narrative revolves around two factions of aliens: the “good” aliens fleeing their dying homeworld of Naratuko and the “evil” aliens responsible for its destruction, pursuing them across the universe. The good aliens genetically revert to a pre-birth state to escape, seeking a sympathetic lifeform to restore them. A later development reveals that all the original aliens are evil, with the “good” aliens plotting to contaminate Earth’s water sources after being discarded. This leads to the release of a “Pure Evil” line of Test Tube Aliens.

The toy itself ðŸ”—

The toy consists of a test tube containing a white cocoon or chrysalis. Adding water dissolves the cocoon, revealing an infant alien. The alien’s “heartbeat” is indicated by flashing lights. The alien requires feeding with “Sloog” and must be kept in a regular cycle of daylight and darkness to remain “healthy.” The alien can detect water levels and will signal if they are too high or too low. If not properly cared for, the alien will “die.” The toy also interacts with a now-defunct website where users could induce coma or panic modes and check the alien’s age and health. A picture of Kurion, a good alien, is included.

How it works ðŸ”—

The alien’s body contains Polyacrylamide, a polymer that expands when it absorbs water. The “Sloog” contains a weak acid that slows the expansion, making the growth appear gradual. Electrodes on the alien’s antenna and head sense the presence of the acid and measure water levels to determine if the alien is “healthy.” A light detector in the alien’s head responds to flashes from the website, tracking light and dark exposure. The Test Tube Alien website is currently offline.

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the sources used in the article, including a Popular Mechanics blog post by Erik Sofge titled “Test Tube Aliens: Gadget of the Week.”

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to an archived version of the official Test Tube Aliens website.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test_Tube_Aliens

item.title: Alien visitation
item.description:
Alien Visitation ðŸ”—

This entry directs readers to the Wiktionary definition of “visitation.”

Alien visitation refers to the concept that intelligent extraterrestrial beings have visited Earth. Several claimed forms of these visitations are listed:

  • Alien abduction: The act of being kidnapped by aliens.
  • Ancient astronaut: The theory that aliens influenced major historical events.
  • Close encounter: The observation of alien vessels.
  • Contactee: A person who claims to have been contacted by aliens.

See also ðŸ”—

This section provides a link to a disambiguation page for the term “Visitation,” indicating that the term has multiple meanings beyond the context of alien encounters. It also includes a disambiguation note that directs users to the correct article if they arrived at this page via an internal link.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_visitation

item.title: Resident Alien
item.description:
Resident Alien is an American science fiction mystery comedy-drama television series created by Chris Sheridan, based on the comic book of the same title by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse, that premiered its 10-episode first season on January 27, 2021, on Syfy. It stars Alan Tudyk in the title role. In March 2021, it was renewed for a second season which premiered January 26, 2022.[2][3] The second season consists of 16 episodes, split into two eight-episode parts; the second half premiered on August 10, 2022.[4][5] In July 2022, it was renewed for an eight-episode third season,[6] which premiered February 14, 2024.[7] In June 2024, it was renewed for a fourth season and will move to USA Network.[8]

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: UFOs: Generals, Pilots, and Government Officials Go on the Record
item.description:
Leslie Kean, a veteran investigative reporter who has spent the past ten years studying the still-unexplained UFO phenomenon, reviewed hundreds of government documents, aviation reports, radar data, and case studies with corroborating physical evidence. She interviewed dozens of high-level officials and aviation witnesses from around the world. Among them, five Air Force generals and a host of high-level sourcesâ€”including Fife Symington III, former governor of Arizona, and Nick Pope, former head of the British Defence Ministryâ€™s UFO Investigative Unitâ€”have written their own breathtaking, firsthand accounts about UFO encounters and investigations exclusively for this book.

With the support of former White House chief of staff John Podesta, Kean lifts the veil on decades of U.S. government misinformation about this mysterious phenomenon and presents irrefutable evidence that unknown flying objectsâ€”metallic, luminous, and seemingly able to maneuver in ways that defy the laws of physicsâ€”actually exist.

Source: UFOs: Generals, Pilots, and Government Officials Go on the Record at Amazon

item.title: UFO: Aftermath
item.description:
UFO: Aftermath is a 2003 real-time tactics/turn-based strategy video game created by ALTAR Interactive. It is a homage to the X-COM game series, with roots in the unfinished game The Dreamland Chronicles: Freedom Ridge. It was followed by two sequels, UFO: Aftershock and UFO: Afterlight

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO:_Aftermath
